title: Sledgehammer (Rihanna song)

text: Barbadian singer Rihanna has released four video albums and appeared in fifty-two music videos, six films, ten television programs, and eight television commercials.
title: Rihanna videography

text: In 2005, Rihanna signed a recording contract with Def Jam Recordings and released her debut single "Pon de Replay", taken from her first studio album "Music of the Sun" (2005).
title: Rihanna videography

text: Like its lyrical theme, the music video for the song was inspired by disco and dance; it was directed by Little X.
title: Rihanna videography

text: Three separate videos were released for "SOS", the lead single from her second studio album "A Girl Like Me" (2006), all of which contained various dance sequences.
title: Rihanna videography

text: The same year, American director Anthony Mandler directed the accompanying music video for the second single "Unfaithful", which featured Rihanna in a dangerous love triangle with her lover and her husband.
title: Rihanna videography

text: "Unfaithful" was Rihanna's first collaboration with Mandler; they later worked together regularly.
title: Rihanna videography

text: Also in 2006, Rihanna played herself in the third installment of the "Bring It On" film series, entitled "".
title: Rihanna videography

text: Robyn Rihanna Fenty ( ; February 20, 1988) is a Barbadian singer, songwriter, and actress.
title: Rihanna

text: Born in Saint Michael, Barbados and raised in Bridgetown, during 2003 she recorded demo tapes under the direction of record producer Evan Rogers and signed a recording contract with Def Jam Recordings after auditioning for its then-president, hip hop producer and rapper Jay Z.
title: Rihanna

text: In 2005, Rihanna rose to fame with the release of her debut studio album "Music of the Sun" and its follow-up "A Girl like Me" (2006), which charted on the top 10 of the US "Billboard" 200 and respectively produced the singles "Pon de Replay" and "SOS".
title: Rihanna

text: Stanislav Kostka Neumann (June 5, 1875, in Prague – June 28, 1947, in Prague) was Czech writer, poet and journalist.
title: Stanislav Kostka Neumann

text: He has undergone many stages of creative: symbolist ("I Am an Apostle of the New Life"), anarchist ("A Dream About a Crowd of Desperate People, and Other Verses"), landscape lyric ("The Book of Forests, Hills, and Waters"), civilist ("New Songs"), communist ("Red Songs") and others.
title: Stanislav Kostka Neumann

text: He was one of the founders of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia.
title: Stanislav Kostka Neumann

text: He was a mentor of Jaroslav Seifert (Seifert was dedicated this his first book).
title: Stanislav Kostka Neumann

text: Ludvík Kundera (22 March 1920 – 17 August 2010) was a Czech writer, translator, poet, playwright, editor and literary historian.
title: Ludvík Kundera

text: He was a notable exponent of the Czech avant-garde literature and a prolific translator of German authors.
title: Ludvík Kundera

text: In 2007, he received the Medal of Merit for service to the Republic.
title: Ludvík Kundera

text: In 2009, he was awarded the "Jaroslav Seifert Award", presented by the Charter 77 Foundation.
title: Ludvík Kundera

text: Kundera was a cousin of Czech-French writer Milan Kundera and nephew of the pianist and musicologist also named Ludvík Kundera.
title: Ludvík Kundera

title: Stoner (novel)

text: Paul Johann Ludwig von Heyse (15 March 1830 – 2 April 1914) was a distinguished German writer and translator.
title: Paul Heyse

text: A member of two important literary societies, the "Tunnel über der Spree" in Berlin and "Die Krokodile" in Munich, he wrote novels, poetry, 177 short stories, and about sixty dramas.
title: Paul Heyse

text: The sum of Heyse's many and varied productions made him a dominant figure among German men of letters.
title: Paul Heyse

text: He was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1910 "as a tribute to the consummate artistry, permeated with idealism, which he has demonstrated during his long productive career as a lyric poet, dramatist, novelist and writer of world-renowned short stories."
title: Paul Heyse

text: Wirsen, one of the Nobel judges, said that "Germany has not had a greater literary genius since Goethe."
title: Paul Heyse

text: Heyse is the fifth oldest laureate in literature, after Doris Lessing, Theodor Mommsen, Alice Munro and Jaroslav Seifert.
title: Paul Heyse

text: The Dark is the second novel by Irish writer John McGahern, published in 1965.

title: Jaroslav Seifert

text: It was originally awarded to authors in exile during the Soviet era.
title: Jaroslav Seifert Prize

text: Memoir (published in North America as "All Will Be Well") is an autobiographical account of the childhood of Irish writer John McGahern.
title: Memoir (John McGahern book)

text: It was published in 2005, and the writer died in 2006.
title: Memoir (John McGahern book)

text: It recalls, amongst other things, his formative years in Leitrim, Ireland, the death of his beloved mother, Susan, and his relationship with his dark and enigmatic father.
title: Memoir (John McGahern book)

text: Themes from his childhood experiences run throughout his canon of fiction.
title: Memoir (John McGahern book)

text: Anthony Hunt (born 1932) is a structural engineer of numerous world-renowned buildings, with a career spanning from the 1950s until his retirement in 2002.
title: Anthony Hunt

text: With a strong interest in both engineering and industrial design, Hunt was a major player in creating the High Tech style of Norman Foster and Richard Rogers.
title: Anthony Hunt

text: He formed Anthony Hunt associates in 1962.
title: Anthony Hunt

text: He worked with Rogers and Foster on Reliance Controls building in Swindon (1966) which was the first building of the High Tech architecture style.
title: Anthony Hunt

text: He was also a structural engineer on the Waterloo International railway station in London (1993).
title: Anthony Hunt

text: Night Shift is a 1982 American comedy film, directed by Ron Howard, concerning a timid night shift morgue employee whose life is turned upside down by a free-spirited entrepreneur.
title: Night Shift (film)

text: The Langley Academy is an academy in Langley, east of Slough in Berkshire, south east England.

text: Geoffrey Norman Foster (16 October 1884 – 11 August 1971) was an English cricketer who played county cricket for Worcestershire and Kent, as well as appearing a number of times for Oxford University and MCC.

title: Geoffrey Foster

text: The Lebanese Third Division (Arabic: الدوري اللبناني - الدرجة الثالثة‎ ‎ ) is the third division of Lebanese football.
title: Lebanese Third Division

text: It is controlled by the Federation Libanaise de Football Association.
title: Lebanese Third Division

text: The 23 teams are divided into 3 groups of 8 teams each.
title: Lebanese Third Division

text: The first two teams of each group qualify to the playoffs and the first two teams of these playoffs qualify to the Lebanese Second Division and replace the relegated teams.
title: Lebanese Third Division

text: On the other hand the last two teams will be submitted to the playoffs that will decide which two of these four teams will be relegated to the Lebanese Fourth Division.
title: Lebanese Third Division

text: The teams play twice against each other once at home and the other away.
title: Lebanese Third Division

text: The 49ers–Giants rivalry is a professional football rivalry between the San Francisco 49ers and the New York Giants.
title: 49ers–Giants rivalry

text: It is one of the great inter-division rivalry games in the NFL.
title: 49ers–Giants rivalry

text: The two teams do not play every year; instead, they play once every three years due to the NFL's rotating division schedules, or if the two teams finish in the same place in their respective divisions, they would play the ensuing season.
title: 49ers–Giants rivalry

text: Since 1982, the 49ers and Giants have met eight times in the postseason (including two NFC Championship Games), the most times two teams have met in the playoffs in the NFL since that time.
title: 49ers–Giants rivalry

text: Kalle Mäkinen (born 1 February 1989) is a Finnish footballer who last played for the Finnish Veikkausliiga club Maskun Palloseura.
title: Kalle Mäkinen

text: He was nicknamed "Sergio" because his style of play was similar to that of Spanish fullback Sergio Ramos
title: Kalle Mäkinen

text: The Bruins–Flyers rivalry is a National Hockey League (NHL) rivalry between the Boston Bruins and Philadelphia Flyers ice hockey clubs.
title: Bruins–Flyers rivalry

text: Both teams compete in the Eastern Conference, but Boston plays in the Atlantic Division and Philadelphia plays in the Metropolitan Division.
title: Bruins–Flyers rivalry

text: The two teams have been rivals since the Flyers inception in the 1967 expansion, but was most intense in the 1970s when the two teams met in four playoff series, including the 1974 Stanley Cup Finals, with the Flyers beating the heavily favored Bruins.
title: Bruins–Flyers rivalry

text: The rivalry was renewed in the 2010s with both teams meeting in the playoffs for two consecutive years, including a 2010 series, with the Flyers overcoming a 3 games to none deficit to win the series.
title: Bruins–Flyers rivalry

text: Historically, both franchises are renowned for their toughness and brawling ways, with the Bruins famously nicknamed the Big Bad Bruins, and the Flyers also famously nicknamed the Broad Street Bullies.
title: Bruins–Flyers rivalry

text: The Segunda División, officially known as La Liga 2 and as La Liga 1|2|3 (stylized as La Liga 1|2|3) for sponsorship reasons, is the second professional association football division of the Spanish football league system.
title: Segunda División

text: Administrated by the Liga de Fútbol Profesional (LFP), it is contested by 22 teams, with the top two teams plus the winner of a play-off promoted to La Liga and replaced by the three lowest-placed teams in that division.
title: Segunda División

text: Sergio Ramos García (] ; born 30 March 1986) is a Spanish professional footballer who plays for and captains both Real Madrid and the Spain national team.
title: Sergio Ramos

text: Primarily a central defender, he can also play as a right back.
title: Sergio Ramos

text: The Spanish football league system refers to the system in Spanish club football that consists of several football leagues bound together hierarchically by promotion and relegation.
title: Spanish football league system

text: Unlike the English and Scottish football federations, the Spanish football federation allows reserve teams to compete in the main football league system, as is the case in most of Europe; however reserve teams are not allowed to compete in the same tier as their senior team, and no reserve team has thus competed in the top flight, Primera División.
title: Spanish football league system

text: The Primera División, commonly known as La Liga and as La Liga Santander for sponsorship reasons with Santander, is the top professional association football division of the Spanish football league system.
title: La Liga

text: Administrated by the Liga de Fútbol Profesional (LFP), La Liga is contested by 20 teams, with the three lowest-placed teams relegated to the Segunda División and replaced by the top two teams in that division plus the winner of a play-off.
title: La Liga

text: The Maryland–West Virginia football rivalry is an American college football rivalry between the Maryland Terrapins and West Virginia Mountaineers.
title: Maryland–West Virginia football rivalry

text: The two schools are strong rivals due to several factors, including similar recruiting areas and the relatively short distance between each other, approximately 210 mi apart.
title: Maryland–West Virginia football rivalry

text: The two teams first played in 1919 and the series ran uninterrupted from 1980 to 2007.
title: Maryland–West Virginia football rivalry

text: West Virginia leads the series 28–22–2.
title: Maryland–West Virginia football rivalry

text: The two teams met for the Gator Bowl for a rematch at the end of the 2003 season.
title: Maryland–West Virginia football rivalry

text: Until the series lapsed in 2007, the game was the longest continuously running non-conference game for both schools.
title: Maryland–West Virginia football rivalry

text: After the 2015 edition in Morgantown, WV, the two teams will not meet again until 2020 in College Park.
title: Maryland–West Virginia football rivalry

text: The Uruguayan Clásico (Spanish: "Clásico del fútbol uruguayo") is the most important rivalry in Uruguayan football and one of the best of the American continent.
title: Uruguayan Clásico

text: It is contested between the two most popular football clubs in Uruguay, Club Nacional de Football and Club Atlético Peñarol (formerly CURCC), both based in Montevideo.
title: Uruguayan Clásico

text: As of 2012, the two teams have won 90 of the 108 Uruguayan Primera División titles, and many international tournaments, including a combined eight Copa Libertadores.
title: Uruguayan Clásico

text: The first meeting between the two teams was at the turn of the century in 1900, making it one of the oldest football rivalries outside Great Britain.
title: Uruguayan Clásico

text: CURCC, which would go on to become Peñarol, won the first match 2–0.
title: Uruguayan Clásico

text: Thomas Barnett (born on March 3rd, 1973) is an American singer-songwriter born in Richmond, Virginia.

title: Thomas Barnett (musician)

text: Barnett has been the vocalist and lyricist for the band since its formation in 1999.

text: He was also the vocalist and primary lyricist for the band Inquisition until its disbanding in 1996.
title: Thomas Barnett (musician)

text: Inquisition reformed for a three show reunion event in May 2007.
title: Thomas Barnett (musician)

text: Strike Anywhere has been inactive since late 2013 and Thomas has joined melodic hardcore supergroup Great Collapse with ex-members of Rise Against and Set Your Goals among others.
title: Thomas Barnett (musician)

text: Sam Sims (born January 10, 1980) is an American singer-songwriter born in Huntsville, Alabama and calls Melbourne, Florida his new home away from home.
title: Sam Sims

text: He began his musical journey at age seven, learning piano from his mother, and start writing original songs by age fourteen.
title: Sam Sims

text: Slaid Cleaves (born June 9, 1964) is an American singer-songwriter born in Washington, D.C. and raised in South Berwick, Maine and Round Pond, Maine, United States.
title: Slaid Cleaves

text: An alumnus of Tufts University, where he majored in English and philosophy, Cleaves lives in Austin, Texas.
title: Slaid Cleaves

text: In the 1970s, the Stovall Sisters were a gospel trio of recording artists consisting of Lillian, Netta, and Joyce Stovall.
title: The Stovall Sisters

text: Definitive works include the album "The Stovall Sisters" (Reprise Records 1970, Warner Music Group) which included the now funk/soul classic “Hang on in There.”
title: The Stovall Sisters

text: They are also the featured background vocalists on the rock classic “Spirit In The Sky” (recorded by Norman Greenbaum, producer, Erik Jacobsen).
title: The Stovall Sisters

text: Aretha Lafayette Henry (born August 1, 1982) is an American singer-songwriter born in Jackson, Mississippi.
title: Aretha Henry

text: Norman Joel Greenbaum (born November 20, 1942) is an American singer-songwriter.
title: Norman Greenbaum

text: He is best known for writing and performing the 1969 song "Spirit in the Sky".
title: Norman Greenbaum

text: Keri Noble (born 1975) is an American singer-songwriter born in Fort Worth, Texas and raised in Detroit.
title: Keri Noble

text: Her father was a Baptist minister, and Noble sang in church as a child.
title: Keri Noble

text: She attended a local Assembly of God school for Junior High and high school in Michigan.
title: Keri Noble

text: She began playing her own music in the Detroit area.
title: Keri Noble

text: After meeting Billy McLaughlin, she moved to Minneapolis, and in 2003 she signed with major label EMI.
title: Keri Noble

text: She has been compared to Norah Jones.
title: Keri Noble

text: She left EMI in 2005 and signed with JVC in Japan where she achieved great success, enabling her to continue to write and perform in the US without the support of a label.
title: Keri Noble

text: Stacy Clark (born September 21, 1980) is an American singer-songwriter born in Buffalo, New York.
title: Stacy Clark

text: John Oszajca (pronounced OH-ZSA-KUH; born May 8, 1974) is an American singer-songwriter born in Hawaii.
title: John Oszajca

text: Shea Seger (born 1979 ) is an American singer-songwriter born in Fort Worth, Texas.
title: Shea Seger

text: Her sound has been likened to a combination of Janis Joplin, Sheryl Crow, Ani DiFranco and Tori Amos.
title: Shea Seger

text: Seger describes her music as "mutt dog... bluesy pop with beats".
title: Shea Seger

text: Donald Trump is an American businessman, former television personality, and the 45th President of the United States.
title: Business career of Donald Trump

text: He began his real estate career at his father's company, Elizabeth Trump and Son, which he later renamed to The Trump Organization.
title: Business career of Donald Trump

text: He rose to public prominence after a number of successful real estate deals in Manhattan and New York City, and his company now owns and develops lodging and golf courses around the world.
title: Business career of Donald Trump

text: Trump partly or completely owned several beauty pageants between 1996 and 2015.
title: Business career of Donald Trump

text: He has marketed his name to many building projects and commercial products.
title: Business career of Donald Trump

text: Trump's unsuccessful business ventures have included several casino and hotel bankruptcies, the folding of his New Jersey Generals football team, and the now-defunct Trump University.
title: Business career of Donald Trump

text: Trump National Golf Club Westchester is a private golf club in Briarcliff Manor, New York.
title: Trump National Golf Club Westchester

text: Owned by Donald Trump, the 45th President of the United States, the 140 acre course has eighteen holes, with a 75000 sqft clubhouse.
title: Trump National Golf Club Westchester

text: Founded in 1922 as "Briarcliff Country Club", it later operated as "Briar Hills Country Club" and "Briar Hall Golf and Country Club" before Trump's purchase of the property in 1996.
title: Trump National Golf Club Westchester

text: Trump renamed the club to match his other golf properties, and after its county, Westchester.
title: Trump National Golf Club Westchester

text: He had the clubhouse and course rebuilt for its 2002 reopening; the course was designed by Jim Fazio.
title: Trump National Golf Club Westchester

text: Donald Trump served as president over Trump National Golf Club LLC (managing the Westchester club) from August 2000 until January 19, 2017, the day before his inauguration.
title: Trump National Golf Club Westchester

text: Frederick Christ Trump Sr. (October 11, 1905 – June 25, 1999) was an American real estate developer and philanthropist, primarily in New York City, and father of Donald Trump, the 45th President of the United States, and Maryanne Trump Barry, a United States Court of Appeals judge.
title: Fred Trump

text: The New York Biltmore Hotel was a luxury hotel in New York City that opened in 1913.
title: New York Biltmore Hotel

text: It was one of three palatial hotels built as part of the Terminal City development.
title: New York Biltmore Hotel

text: The others were the Commodore Hotel (currently Grand Hyatt New York), and the Roosevelt Hotel, which is still in operation.
title: New York Biltmore Hotel

text: The Twin Towers II (also known as Twin Towers 2, New Twin Towers, Trump Twin Towers and World Trade Center Phoenix ) was a proposed twin-towered supertall skyscraper complex which would have been located at the World Trade Center site in Manhattan, New York City.
title: Twin Towers 2

text: The proposed complex would have replaced the former Twin Towers of the World Trade Center destroyed in the September 11 attacks, restoring the skyline of the city to its former state.
title: Twin Towers 2

text: The main design for the proposed complex would feature new landmark twin towers, identical to the originals designed by Minoru Yamasaki, though it would feature 115 stories—5 floors taller than the originals, among other differences.
title: Twin Towers 2

text: Beside the towers, an above-ground memorial would have occupied the footprints of the original towers.
title: Twin Towers 2

text: The new site would also have featured three 12-story buildings, replacing the original 3, 4 and 5 World Trade Center.
title: Twin Towers 2

text: The complex was designed and developed by American architect Herbert Belton and American engineer Kenneth Gardner, and sponsored by businessman and 45th President of the United States, Donald Trump.
title: Twin Towers 2

text: The United States presidential election of 2016 was the 58th quadrennial American presidential election, held on Tuesday, November 8, 2016.
title: United States presidential election, 2016

text: In a surprise victory, the Republican ticket of businessman Donald Trump and Indiana Governor Mike Pence defeated the Democratic ticket of former First Lady, U.S. Senator of New York and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and U.S. Senator from Virginia Tim Kaine.
title: United States presidential election, 2016

text: Trump took office as the 45th President, and Pence as the 48th Vice President, on January 20, 2017.
title: United States presidential election, 2016

text: Concurrent with the presidential election, Senate, House, and many gubernatorial and state and local elections were also held on November 8.
title: United States presidential election, 2016

text: American businessman, politician, and 45th President of the United States, Donald Trump, has used several pseudonyms, including "John Barron" (or "John Baron") and "John Miller".
title: Donald Trump pseudonyms

text: His habit of sometimes speaking to the media under the guise of a spokesperson has been described as "an open secret" at the Trump Organization and in New York media circles.
title: Donald Trump pseudonyms

text: Some New York editors recalled that "calls from Barron were at points so common that they became a recurring joke on the city desk."
title: Donald Trump pseudonyms

text: A writer for "Fortune" reported that Trump's father Fred Trump had used a pseudonym ("Mr. Green") in business dealings.
title: Donald Trump pseudonyms

text: Donald John Trump (born June 14, 1946) is the 45th and current President of the United States, in office since January 20, 2017.
title: Donald Trump

text: Before entering politics, he was a businessman and television personality.
title: Donald Trump

text: The presidency of Donald Trump began at noon EST on January 20, 2017, when Donald Trump was inaugurated as the 45th President of the United States, succeeding Barack Obama.
title: Presidency of Donald Trump

text: Trump, the Republican nominee, was a businessman and reality television personality from New York City at the time of his victory in the 2016 presidential election over the Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton.
title: Presidency of Donald Trump

text: His running mate, former Governor Mike Pence of Indiana, took office as the 48th Vice President of the United States on the same day.
title: Presidency of Donald Trump

text: Trump's term in office is set to end on January 20, 2021, though he is eligible for election to a second term and has declared his intention to run.
title: Presidency of Donald Trump

text: The Grand Hyatt New York is a hotel located directly east of the Grand Central Terminal in Midtown Manhattan, New York City.
title: Grand Hyatt New York

text: It was originally built and opened on January 28, 1919, as The Commodore Hotel.
title: Grand Hyatt New York

text: In 1980, Donald Trump modernized the outside of the building and renovated the inside as part of his first construction project in Manhattan.
title: Grand Hyatt New York

text: Variable universal life insurance (often shortened to VUL) is a type of life insurance that builds a cash value.
title: Variable universal life insurance

text: In a VUL, the cash value can be invested in a wide variety of separate accounts, similar to mutual funds, and the choice of which of the available separate accounts to use is entirely up to the contract owner.
title: Variable universal life insurance

text: The 'variable' component in the name refers to this ability to invest in separate accounts whose values vary—they vary because they are invested in stock and/or bond markets.
title: Variable universal life insurance

text: The 'universal' component in the name refers to the flexibility the owner has in making premium payments.
title: Variable universal life insurance

text: The premiums can vary from nothing in a given month up to maximums defined by the Internal Revenue Code for life insurance.
title: Variable universal life insurance

text: This flexibility is in contrast to whole life insurance that has fixed premium payments that typically cannot be missed without lapsing the policy (although one may exercise an Automatic Premium Loan feature, or surrender dividends to pay a Whole Life premium).
title: Variable universal life insurance

text: In finance, the time value (TV) ("extrinsic" or "instrumental" value) of an option is the premium a rational investor would pay over its "current" exercise value (intrinsic value), based on the probability it will increase in value before expiry.
title: Option time value

text: For an American option this value is always greater than zero in a fair market, thus an option is "always" worth more than its current exercise value.
title: Option time value

text: As an option can be thought of as 'price insurance' (e.g., an airline insuring against unexpected soaring fuel costs caused by a hurricane), TV can be thought of as the "risk premium" the option seller charges the buyer—the higher the expected risk (volatility formula_1 time), the higher the premium.
title: Option time value

text: Conversely, TV can be thought of as the price an investor is willing to pay for potential upside.
title: Option time value

text: Sunday is a sleep focussed start-up in India founded by Alphonse Reddy, – who is also the founder of Fabmart.com, a retail venture that sells premium sleep products – in September 2015.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: Sunday mattresses are manufactured and retailed by MRPL (Madanapalle Retail Private Ltd).
title: Sunday Mattress

text: Sunday sources its raw materials from four different countries, including Belgium.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: The mattresses have been designed by Japanese designer Hiroko Shiratori, who is the founding member of London based design collective OKAY studio.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: Apart from selling online through its website, the company also retails in Bangalore.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: The company sells two mattress variants — Ortho plus and Latex Plus, and follows omni-channel sales strategy.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: Its online sales are augmented by an experience centre in Bangalore.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: Sunday like other sleep start-ups follows a 100 Nights Trial offer, where customers can return the product and get a full refund if they are not satisfied with the purchase.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: The product range includes mattresses, pillows, toppers and protector pads.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: Sunday offers value additions such as same day delivery & Try’N’Pay in Bangalore and Hyderabad.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: Sunday mattress is one of the best options in the mid and premium range.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: Sunday is funded by Anand Morzaria, entrepreneur in the ITES space, and his team.
title: Sunday Mattress

text: When the predecessor of international fast food restaurant chain Burger King (BK) first opened in 1955, its menu predominantly consisted of hamburgers, French fries, soft drinks, milkshakes, and desserts.
title: List of Burger King products

text: After being acquired by its Miami, Florida franchisees and renamed in 1954, BK began expanding its menu by adding the Whopper.
title: List of Burger King products

text: The company did not add another permanent hamburger to its menu until the introduction of the Big King sandwich in 1996 in response to McDonald's Big Mac sandwich.
title: List of Burger King products

text: The company began experimenting with premium hamburgers, made from higher quality ingredients, in 1978 with the introduction of its Specialty Sandwich product line.
title: List of Burger King products

text: The products were some of the first designed by a fast food restaurant chain that were intended to capture the adult market, members of which would be willing to spend more on a higher-quality product.
title: List of Burger King products

text: However, it wasn't until 2002 when the company began to work on a premium burger in earnest.
title: List of Burger King products

text: On the value side, Burger King first started offering sliders to its menu in the mid-1980s and offered them off and on for the next twenty years.
title: List of Burger King products

text: John Clifton "Jack" Bogle (born May 8, 1929) is an American investor, business magnate, and philanthropist.
title: John C. Bogle

text: He is the founder and retired chief executive of The Vanguard Group.
title: John C. Bogle

text: The forward premium anomaly in currency markets (also referred to as the forward premium puzzle or the Fama puzzle) refers to the well documented empirical finding that the domestic currency is expected to appreciate when domestic nominal interest rates exceed foreign interest rates.
title: Forward premium anomaly

text: This is puzzling because economic theory suggests that if all currencies are equally risky investors would demand higher interest rates on currencies expected to "fall" in value.
title: Forward premium anomaly

text: See: Forward exchange rate# Unbiasedness hypothesis.
title: Forward premium anomaly

text: Minority discount is an economic concept reflecting the notion that a partial ownership interest may be worth less than its proportional share of the total business.
title: Minority discount

text: The concept applies to equities with voting power because the size of voting position provides additional benefits or drawbacks.
title: Minority discount

text: For example, ownership of a 51% share in the business is usually worth more than 51% of its equity value—this phenomenon is called the premium for control.
title: Minority discount

text: Conversely, ownership of a 30% share in the business may be worth less than 30% of its equity value.
title: Minority discount

text: This is so because this minority ownership limits the scope of control over critical aspects of the business.
title: Minority discount

text: Share prices of public companies usually reflect the minority discount.
title: Minority discount

text: This is why take-private transactions involve a substantial premium over recently quoted prices.
title: Minority discount

text: Universal life insurance (often shortened to UL) is a type of cash value life insurance, sold primarily in the United States of America.
title: Universal life insurance

text: Under the terms of the policy, the excess of premium payments above the current cost of insurance is credited to the cash value of the policy.
title: Universal life insurance

text: The cash value is credited each month with interest, and the policy is debited each month by a cost of insurance (COI) charge, as well as any other policy charges and fees drawn from the cash value, even if no premium payment is made that month.
title: Universal life insurance

text: Interest credited to the account is determined by the insurer, but has a contractual minimum rate (often 2%).
title: Universal life insurance

text: When an earnings rate is pegged to a financial index such as a stock, bond or other interest rate index, the policy is an "Indexed Universal Life" contract.
title: Universal life insurance

text: These types of policies offer the advantage of guaranteed level premiums throughout the insured's lifetime at substantially lower premium cost than an equivalent whole life policy at first; the cost of insurance is always increasing as found on the cost index table (usually p. 3 of a contract).
title: Universal life insurance

text: This not only allows for easy comparison of costs between carriers, but also works well in irrevocable life insurance trusts (ILIT's) since cash is of no consequence.
title: Universal life insurance

text: In investing, value premium refers to the greater risk-adjusted return of value stocks over growth stocks.
title: Value premium

text: Eugene Fama and K. G. French first identified the premium in 1992, using a measure they called HML (high book-to-market ratio minus low book-to-market ratio) to measure equity returns based on valuation.
title: Value premium

text: Other experts, such as John C. Bogle, have argued that no value premium exists, claiming that Fama and French's research is period dependent.
title: Value premium

text: Tesco venture brands are an advanced form of private label brands launched by Tesco in 2011 that do not carry the retailer name.
title: Tesco Venture Brands

text: These products fall under the category of Tesco venture brands and complement their current value, standard and finest ranges.
title: Tesco Venture Brands

text: Tesco venture branded goods are available in a wide range of industries from food to children's toys to sanitary products.
title: Tesco Venture Brands

text: Most of the brands are positioned as "premium goods" competing with existing premium branded goods.
title: Tesco Venture Brands

text: Hampden–Sydney College, also known as H–SC, is a liberal arts college for men located in Hampden Sydney, Virginia, United States.
title: Hampden–Sydney College

text: Founded in 1775, Hampden–Sydney is the oldest private charter college in the Southern U.S., the 10th oldest college in the U.S., the last college founded before the American Revolution, and one of only three four-year, all-men's liberal arts colleges in the United States.
title: Hampden–Sydney College

text: Hampden–Sydney College is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and the Virginia Landmarks Register.
title: Hampden–Sydney College

text: Watauga Residential College (formerly Watauga Global Community) is a residential college founded at Appalachian State University in 1972.
title: Watauga Residential College

text: Watauga College was founded to be an "interdisciplinary, experimental, residential, coed alternative for social science and humanities general education requirements."
title: Watauga Residential College

text: Watauga Residential college was developed as "response to rising criticism of American education during the sixties and to the artificial fragmentation of knowledge in the academy; it was seen as a return to the world, where problems and themes do not recognize disciplinary boundaries and education is reconnected with individual learners."
title: Watauga Residential College

text: Although Watauga has changed names over the years Watauga College in 1972, Watauga Global Community in 2008, and Watauga Residential College in 2014, its mission has remained relatively the same.
title: Watauga Residential College

text: "Watauga Residential College pursues its mission through a sequenced, interdisciplinary, experiential curriculum that requires students to integrate class content, community-based research, and multicultural immersion.
title: Watauga Residential College

text: This innovative curriculum, in conjunction with the academic and residential community, creates an atmosphere for the emergence of dynamic learning experiences through unique interactions among students and faculty."
title: Watauga Residential College

text: A key focus of Watauga is on the residential community so for the first year students are required to live in the living learning center.
title: Watauga Residential College

text: Willard Uphaus (November 27, 1890 – October 5, 1983) was an American theologian and pacifist.
title: Willard Uphaus

text: Uphaus was born on a farm in rural Delaware County, Indiana, and attended nearby Earlham College, a liberal arts college founded by the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers), in Richmond, Indiana, graduating in 1913.
title: Willard Uphaus

text: Uphaus went on to earn his PhD in the psychology of religion at Yale University, and subsequently taught at Vanderbilt University Divinity School in Nashville, Tennessee, and Hastings College in Hastings, Nebraska.
title: Willard Uphaus

text: In 1930, Uphaus was dismissed from Hastings for theological interpretations and his leftist viewpoints.
title: Willard Uphaus

text: Subsequently, six department heads resigned from Hastings in protest.
title: Willard Uphaus

text: William Claflin (March 6, 1818 – January 5, 1905) was an American politician, industrialist and philanthropist from Massachusetts.
title: William Claflin

text: He served as the 27th Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts from 1869–1872 and as a member of the United States Congress from 1877–1881.
title: William Claflin

text: He also served as chairman of the Republican National Committee from 1868–1872, serving as a moderating force between the Radical and moderate wings of the Republican Party.
title: William Claflin

text: His name is given to Claflin University in South Carolina, a historically black college founded with funding from him and his father.
title: William Claflin

text: Berkshire Community College is an accredited, co-educational two-year community college in Berkshire County, Massachusetts.
title: Berkshire Community College

text: Its primary campus is in Pittsfield, Massachusetts, with a satellite campus in Great Barrington, Massachusetts and classroom spaces in the city of Pittsfield.
title: Berkshire Community College

text: Established in the 1960s, it is the oldest college founded by the Massachusetts Community Colleges Executive Office.
title: Berkshire Community College

text: Tufts University is a private research university incorporated in the municipality of Medford, Massachusetts, United States.
title: Tufts University

text: Tufts College was founded in 1852 by Christian Universalists who worked for years to open a nonsectarian institution of higher learning.
title: Tufts University

text: Charles Tufts donated the land for the campus on Walnut Hill, the highest point in Medford, saying that he wanted to set a "light on the hill".
title: Tufts University

text: The name was changed to Tufts University in 1954, although the corporate name remains "the Trustees of Tufts College".
title: Tufts University

text: For more than a century, Tufts was a small New England liberal arts college until its transformation into a larger research university in the 1970s.
title: Tufts University

text: Tufts is a charter member of the New England Small College Athletic Conference (NESCAC).
title: Tufts University

text: In 2017, the university accepted 14.8% of undergraduate applicants from a pool of 21,101.
title: Tufts University

text: In 2016, it was ranked 27th nationally and 156th internationally by "U.S. News & World Report".
title: Tufts University

text: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya (Sinhala: ශාරිපුත්‍ර මහා විද්‍යාලය) is a secondary school in Imbulpe, Balangoda, Sabaragamuwa Province, Sri Lanka.
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: It was established in the 19th century.
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: At present, more than 800 students are studying at the college .
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: According to ancient documents, it was the first school in balangoda education zone .
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: Many politicians, lawyers,scholars, physicians,engineers,and other government officers studied at this college.
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: Government graduated teachers and other education college's teachers are conduct the class for student up to G.C.E.(A/L).
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: Normally,1st or 2nd level government education service officer is appointed as the principal of the college.
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: there are Buddhist and Roman Catholic educational backgrounds .
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: Also according to the department of education, students of the college follow the local syllabus and face to a/l and o/l examinations which are conducted by government of Sri Lanka .
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: According to the history of the college, it was established as boy's college however after 1950's it was converted into the mixed school by the government .
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: Also according to the official document and students roll of the college founded principal of the college was Mr. Silva and the first student was Mr. Appusincho.
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: Also,college has more than 15 acres premise in Madagedaragoda, Imbulpe .
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: college conduct their science and computer laboratory class in the full facilitated laboratory .
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: one of the laboratories was a present of Hon. Srimao Bandaranayake in 1975.
title: Sri Shariputhra Maha Vidyalaya

text: The Vivian Fowler Memorial College For Girls is an all-girls Independent college founded in 1991 by Chief Mrs. Leila Fowler in Nigeria.
title: Vivian Fowler Memorial College for Girls

text: It is located in the Ikeja suburb of the city of Lagos, the capital of Lagos State.
title: Vivian Fowler Memorial College for Girls

text: It serves to prepare girls for additional private education either at a university in Nigeria or elsewhere in the world.
title: Vivian Fowler Memorial College for Girls

text: It is Classified as one of the most prestigious private schools in western Africa, with students from families of extreme wealth and political power.
title: Vivian Fowler Memorial College for Girls

text: Sherman College of Chiropractic is a private college founded in 1973 named after chiropractor Lyle Sherman.
title: Sherman College of Chiropractic

text: Sherman College offers the doctor of chiropractic degree.
title: Sherman College of Chiropractic

text: The college is home to approximately 450 students representing 42 states and 13 countries and has more than 3,000 alumni around the world.
title: Sherman College of Chiropractic

text: Sherman college supports the "straight" vertebral subluxation-based focus as different from diagnosis and symptomatic treatment focus of "mixed" U.S. chiropractic schools.
title: Sherman College of Chiropractic

text: The name of the college was changed to Sherman College of Straight Chiropractic the late 1970s, but changed back to the original name in 2009.
title: Sherman College of Chiropractic

text: Sherman College also has digital x-ray services in the Health Center for use of interns and local chiropractors.
title: Sherman College of Chiropractic

text: Vivian Winona Pinn (born 1941) is an American physician, scientist and pathologist known for her advocacy of women's health issues and concerns, particularly for assuring that federally funded medical studies include female patients, and well as encouraging women to follow medical and scientific careers.
title: Vivian Pinn

text: Before her retirement in 2011, she had served as associate director for research on women's health at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and had directed NIH's Office of Research on Women's Health.
title: Vivian Pinn

text: Pinn also previously taught at Harvard University and Tufts University (where she also served as assistant dean of student and minority affairs) in Massachusetts, as well as Howard University College of Medicine (where she also chaired the Department of Pathology) in Washington, D.C.
title: Vivian Pinn

text: Since retiring from NIH, Pinn has continued working as a senior scientist emerita at NIH's Fogarty International Center.
title: Vivian Pinn

text: Hayes Alan Jenkins (born March 23, 1933) is a retired American figure skater.
title: Hayes Alan Jenkins

text: He won four consecutive World Figure Skating Championships from 1953 to 1956.
title: Hayes Alan Jenkins

text: He also won the gold medal in the 1956 Winter Olympics, after placing 4th in the 1952 Winter Olympics.
title: Hayes Alan Jenkins

text: His brother David Jenkins won the gold in 1960.
title: Hayes Alan Jenkins

text: Jenkins later married Carol Heiss, the 1956 Olympic silver medalist and the 1960 Olympic gold medalist.
title: Hayes Alan Jenkins

text: The couple had three children, but none of them became a competitive figure skater.
title: Hayes Alan Jenkins

text: David Jacques Pelletier (born November 22, 1974) is a Canadian pairs figure skater.
title: David Pelletier

text: With his partner Jamie Salé, he was the co-gold medal winner at the 2002 Olympic Winter Games.
title: David Pelletier

text: They shared the gold medal with the Russian pair Elena Berezhnaya and Anton Sikharulidze after the 2002 Olympic Winter Games figure skating scandal.
title: David Pelletier

text: Gillis Emanuel Grafström (7 June 1893 – 14 April 1938) was a Swedish figure skater.
title: Gillis Grafström

text: He was born in Stockholm, Sweden.
title: Gillis Grafström

text: He won three successive Olympic gold medals in Men's Figure Skating (1920, 1924, 1928) as well as an Olympic silver medal in the same event in 1932, and three World Championships (1922, 1924, 1929).
title: Gillis Grafström

text: He and Eddie Eagan are the only athletes to have won a gold medal at both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games.
title: Gillis Grafström

text: Grafström has the further distinction of being the only person to have won an individual gold medal in both the Summer (1920) and Winter Olympics (1924, 1928), although Eagan remains the only one to have managed the feat in different disciplines.
title: Gillis Grafström

text: Grafstrom is one of the few athletes who have competed in both the Summer and Winter Olympic games.
title: Gillis Grafström

text: Oksana Baiul (born November 16, 1977) is a Ukrainian former competitive figure skater.
title: Oksana Baiul

text: She is the 1993 World champion and the 1994 Olympic champion in ladies' singles.
title: Oksana Baiul

text: The 1994 Winter Olympics (Norwegian: "Olympiske vinterleker 1994" ), officially known as the XVII Olympic Winter Games (French: Les "XVIIes Jeux olympiques d'hiver"), was a winter multi-sport event celebrated from 12 to 27 February 1994 in and around Lillehammer, Norway.
title: 1994 Winter Olympics

text: Lillehammer failed to win the bid for the 1992 event, losing to Albertville respectively.
title: 1994 Winter Olympics

text: Lillehammer was awarded the 1994 Winter Olympics in 1988, after beating Anchorage, United States; Östersund, Sweden; and Sofia, Bulgaria.
title: 1994 Winter Olympics

text: Lillehammer is the northernmost city to ever host the Winter Games.
title: 1994 Winter Olympics

text: The Games were the first to be held in a different year from the Summer Olympics, the first and only one to be held two years after the previous winter games, and the most recent to be held in a small town.
title: 1994 Winter Olympics

text: The Games were the second Winter Olympics hosted in Norway, after the 1952 Winter Olympics in Oslo, and the fourth Olympics in the Nordic countries, after the 1912 Summer Olympics in Stockholm, Sweden, and the 1952 Summer Olympics in Helsinki, Finland.
title: 1994 Winter Olympics

text: The 2014 Winter Olympics, officially known as the XXII Olympic Winter Games, were a winter multi-sport event held in Sochi, Russia, from 7 February to 23 February.
title: 2014 Winter Olympics medal table

text: A total of 2,873 athletes from 88 nations participated in 98 events in 7 sports across 15 different disciplines.
title: 2014 Winter Olympics medal table

text: Of all athletes, 187 of them representing 26 different countries won medals.
title: 2014 Winter Olympics medal table

text: The Netherlands achieved four podium sweeps in the speed skating, dominating the men's 500 metres, men's 5,000 metres, men's 10,000 metres, and women's 1,500 metres, surpassing the previous record of two podium sweeps.
title: 2014 Winter Olympics medal table

text: Host nation Russia matched the Soviet Union's 1976 achievement of thirteen gold medals and achieved the leading position on the medal table, making the 2014 Winter Games the fourth where the host nation topped the gold medal count.
title: 2014 Winter Olympics medal table

text: Slovenia won its first gold medal in alpine skiing, in the first Winter Olympic gold medal tie.
title: 2014 Winter Olympics medal table

text: Luger Armin Zöggeler of Italy became the first athlete to achieve six Winter Olympic medals over six consecutive games, all achieved at the men's singles event.
title: 2014 Winter Olympics medal table

text: Shizuka Arakawa (荒川 静香 , Arakawa Shizuka , born December 29, 1981) is a Japanese figure skater.
title: Shizuka Arakawa

text: She is the 2006 Olympic Champion and the 2004 World Champion.
title: Shizuka Arakawa

text: Arakawa is the first Japanese skater to win an Olympic gold medal in figure skating and the second Japanese skater to win any Olympic medal in figure skating, after Midori Ito, who won silver in 1992.
title: Shizuka Arakawa

text: She is also the second Japanese woman to win a gold medal at the Winter Olympics, following skier Tae Satoya.
title: Shizuka Arakawa

text: She was the only Japanese medalist at the 2006 Winter Olympics.
title: Shizuka Arakawa

text: Ukraine competed at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, from 7 to 23 February 2014.
title: Ukraine at the 2014 Winter Olympics

text: The National Olympic Committee of Ukraine sent a total of 45 athletes.
title: Ukraine at the 2014 Winter Olympics

text: The women's relay victory gave Ukraine its second Winter Games gold medal ever.
title: Ukraine at the 2014 Winter Olympics

text: The first was won by Oksana Baiul at the 1994 Winter Olympics.
title: Ukraine at the 2014 Winter Olympics

text: On 22 February, cross-country skier Marina Lisogor was excluded from the Olympics after testing positive for trimetazidine.
title: Ukraine at the 2014 Winter Olympics

text: Charlène G. von Saher (born 4 December 1974) is a British former competitive figure skater.
title: Charlene von Saher

text: The daughter of a West German skater, von Saher spent most of her life in Greenwich, Connecticut and trained alongside Nancy Kerrigan under coaches Evy Scotvold and Mary Scotvold.
title: Charlene von Saher

text: She won the gold medal at the 1993 British Championships and then finished 12th at the 1993 World Championships.
title: Charlene von Saher

text: Despite withdrawing from the 1994 national championships with a severe case of the flu, she was selected to represent Great Britain at the 1994 Winter Olympics.
title: Charlene von Saher

text: She finished 15th at the Lillehammer Games.
title: Charlene von Saher

text: Brian Ernest Orser, OC (born 18 December 1961) is a Canadian former competitive and professional figure skater.
title: Brian Orser

text: He is the 1984 and 1988 Olympic silver medalist, 1987 World champion and eight-time (1981–88) Canadian national champion.
title: Brian Orser

text: At the 1988 Winter Olympics, the rivalry between Orser and American figure skater Brian Boitano, who were the two favorites to win the gold medal, captured media attention and was described as the "Battle of the Brians".
title: Brian Orser

text: Impact India Foundation's Community Health Initiative (CHI) covers 1.5 million backward tribals in the State.
title: Community Health Initiative (CHI)

text: CHI aims at the reduction of existing disabilities and incidence of future disabilities through prevention and cure using existing delivery systems and available infrastructure, in partnership with Government, NGOS and local community.
title: Community Health Initiative (CHI)

text: CHI has achieved 72% reduction in disability in Thane District, Maharashtra (2005 to 2012), using existing infrastructure and available delivery systems.
title: Community Health Initiative (CHI)

text: The CHI is a well-integrated set of "preventive health programmes" aimed at the holistic improvement of the health of the community, with specific focus on Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn & Child Health + Adolescent (RMNCH +A).
title: Community Health Initiative (CHI)

text: The CHI activities are in support of the goals of the National Health Mission and in consonance with the United Nations’ Millennium and Sustainable Development Goals-2015.
title: Community Health Initiative (CHI)

text: STREAMS® Integrated Intelligent Transport System is an enterprise traffic management system designed to operate in the Microsoft Windows environment.
title: STREAMS Integrated Intelligent Transport System

text: Like most traffic management systems, STREAMS® is an array of institutional, human, hardware, and software components designed to monitor, control, and manage traffic on streets and highways.
title: STREAMS Integrated Intelligent Transport System

text: Advanced traffic management systems come under the banner of ITS (intelligent transport systems).
title: STREAMS Integrated Intelligent Transport System

text: ITS is an umbrella term referring to the application of information and communications technology to transport operations in order to reduce operating costs, improve safety and maximise the capacity of existing infrastructure.
title: STREAMS Integrated Intelligent Transport System

text: STREAMS® provides traffic signal management, incident management, motorway management, vehicle priority, traveller information, flood monitoring and parking guidance within a single integrated system.
title: STREAMS Integrated Intelligent Transport System

text: STREAMS® is developed by Transmax®.
title: STREAMS Integrated Intelligent Transport System

text: High-speed rail is emerging in Europe as an increasingly popular and efficient means of transport.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: The first high-speed rail lines in Europe, built in the 1980s and 1990s, improved travel times on intra-national corridors.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: Since then, several countries have built extensive high-speed networks, and there are now several cross-border high-speed rail links.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: Railway operators frequently run international services, and tracks are continuously being built and upgraded to international standards on the emerging European high-speed rail network.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: In 2007, a consortium of European railway operators, Railteam, emerged to co-ordinate and boost cross-border high-speed rail travel.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: Developing a Trans-European high-speed rail network is a stated goal of the European Union, and most cross-border railway lines receive EU funding.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: Several countries — France, Spain, Italy, Germany, Austria, Sweden, Belgium, the Netherlands, Russia and the United Kingdom — are connected to a cross-border high-speed railway network.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: More are expected to be connected in the coming years as Europe invests heavily in tunnels, bridges and other infrastructure and development projects across the continent, many of which are under construction now.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: Alstom was the first manufacturer to design and deliver a high speed train or HS-Train, which ended up in service with TGV in France.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: Currently, there are a number of high-level manufacturers designing and building HSR in Europe, with criss-crossed alliances and partnerships, including Canadian company Bombardier, Alstom itself, the Spanish Talgo and the German Siemens.
title: High-speed rail in Europe

text: Rocket Jets was an attraction in Disneyland at the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California.
title: Rocket Jets

text: This attraction opened in 1967 with the new Tomorrowland and closed in 1997 for the 1998 New Tomorrowland.
title: Rocket Jets

text: It was the third spinning rocket attraction in Tomorrowland and stood three stories above the ground.
title: Rocket Jets

text: When Tomorrowland was redone for 1998, the Rocket Jets were replaced by a new attraction based on Orbitron at the entrance to Discoveryland in Disneyland Park Paris.
title: Rocket Jets

text: The PeopleMover, sometimes referred to as the Goodyear PeopleMover and WEDWay PeopleMover, was a transport attraction that operated from July 2, 1967 to August 21, 1995 in Tomorrowland at Disneyland in Anaheim, California.
title: PeopleMover

text: Guests boarded small trains that ran on elevated tracks for a "grand circle tour" above Tomorrowland.
title: PeopleMover

text: The ride's station and track infrastructure remain standing but not operating.
title: PeopleMover

text: A second PeopleMover, known as the WEDway PeopleMover, of a somewhat different design, opened at the Magic Kingdom in Walt Disney World, Florida in 1975, and operated from 1994 to 2009 as the Tomorrowland Transit Authority until being renamed "Tomorrowland Transit Authority PeopleMover" on August 5, 2010, and is still operating today.
title: PeopleMover

text: The legacy of the Soviet Union lives on in the infrastructure of Central Asia.
title: Soviet infrastructure in Central Asia

text: As it crumbles, or gets patched up, much of what was built in Central Asia is the backbone of the existing infrastructure for transportation, goods delivery and energy distribution.
title: Soviet infrastructure in Central Asia

text: Much of the industrial infrastructure underwent precipitous decline in the 1990s, after the fall of the Soviet Union, especially in Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan.
title: Soviet infrastructure in Central Asia

text: The roads, railroads and energy lines are thus oriented towards the Russian Federation and away from other regional neighbors, such as China, Afghanistan or Iran.
title: Soviet infrastructure in Central Asia

text: Rail Users Ireland (previously Platform 11) is a rail transport pressure group in Ireland whose agenda is centred on the idea that there is an economic case for expanding rail transport in Ireland through better utilisation of existing infrastructure with only justified expansion of existing routes.
title: Rail Users Ireland

text: Through press releases, lobbying and leafleting they have promoted the DART Underground, a proposal to build a tunnel south of the Liffey to link up Dublin's Heuston Station with the existing DART and Luas lines.
title: Rail Users Ireland

text: The group is a member of the European Passengers Federation a European level representative body for rail users which shares the same outlook in terms of sustainable transport provision and improving standards on public transport.
title: Rail Users Ireland

text: Storm Hardening is the process whereby construction is used to create new infrastructure or retrofit existing infrastructure such that it is more capable of withstanding extreme weather events.
title: Storm Hardening

text: It "involves physically changing infrastructure to make it less susceptible to damage from extreme wind, flooding, or flying debris.
title: Storm Hardening

text: Hardening measures include adopting new technology, installing new equipment, constructing protective barriers, or changing communications/IT at the facility.
title: Storm Hardening

text: Hardening usually requires significant investment by the energy company.
title: Storm Hardening

text: Some projects take years to complete; for example, large earth-moving equipment may be brought in to build a new levee.
title: Storm Hardening

text: Sometimes the sheer magnitude of assets involved (e.g., thousands of wooden distribution poles) requires years of concerted effort to upgrade."
title: Storm Hardening

text: Rocket Rods was a high-speed thrill attraction in Tomorrowland at Disneyland in Anaheim, California.
title: Rocket Rods

text: The ride, meant to evoke a futuristic rapid transit system, opened in 1998 on the existing PeopleMover infrastructure as part of the New Tomorrowland project.
title: Rocket Rods

text: Plagued with technical problems, Rocket Rods closed permanently in September 2000 after a little over two years of intermittent operation.
title: Rocket Rods

text: Rocket Rods was replaced with Buzz Lightyear Astro Blasters in 2005.
title: Rocket Rods

text: Redd Rockett's Pizza Port is a restaurant located at Tomorrowland of Disneyland at the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California.
title: Redd Rockett's Pizza Port

text: It is themed after a retro space port cafeteria.
title: Redd Rockett's Pizza Port

text: The restaurant opened together with the New Tomorrowland on May 22, 1998 which opened with Astro Orbitor, Honey, I Shrunk the Audience, and Rocket Rods.
title: Redd Rockett's Pizza Port

text: It replaced the former Mission to Mars attraction.
title: Redd Rockett's Pizza Port

text: It is known for its Chicken Fusilli.
title: Redd Rockett's Pizza Port

text: It is across from the Starcade, and directly underneath Space Mountain.
title: Redd Rockett's Pizza Port

text: Heterobasidion annosum is a basidiomycete fungus in the family Bondarzewiaceae.
title: Heterobasidion annosum

text: It is considered to be the most economically important forest pathogen in the Northern Hemisphere.
title: Heterobasidion annosum

text: "Heterobasidion annosum" is widespread in forests in the United States and is responsible for the loss of one billion U.S. dollars annually.
title: Heterobasidion annosum

text: This fungus has been known by many different names.
title: Heterobasidion annosum

text: Commonly, it is also known as annosum root rot.
title: Heterobasidion annosum

text: First described by Fries in 1821, it was known by the name "Polyporus annosum".
title: Heterobasidion annosum

text: Later, it was found to be linked to conifer disease by Robert Hartig in 1874, and was renamed "Fomes annosus" by H. Karsten.
title: Heterobasidion annosum

text: Its current name of "Heterobasidion annosum" was given by Brefeld in 1888.
title: Heterobasidion annosum

text: "Heterobasidion annosum" is one of the most destructive diseases of conifers.
title: Heterobasidion annosum

text: Aseroe rubra, commonly known as the anemone stinkhorn, sea anemone fungus and starfish fungus, is a common and widespread basidiomycete fungus recognizable for its foul odour of carrion and its sea anemone shape when mature.
title: Aseroe rubra

text: Found in gardens on mulch and in grassy areas, it resembles a red star-shaped structure covered in brownish slime on a white stalk.
title: Aseroe rubra

text: It attracts flies, which spread its spores.
title: Aseroe rubra

text: Funki Porcini is the stage name of English musician and film maker James Braddell.
title: Funki Porcini

text: His music is a combination of downtempo, breakbeat and nu jazz with highlights of samples and time-stretched vocals.
title: Funki Porcini

text: The name "Funki Porcini" is a twist on "Funghi Porcini", the Italian name of the mushroom Boletus edulis, commonly known as "penny bun".
title: Funki Porcini

text: Clathrus columnatus, commonly known as the column stinkhorn, is a saprobic species of basidiomycete fungus in the family Phallaceae.
title: Clathrus columnatus

text: It has a widespread distribution, and has been found in Africa, Australasia, and the Americas.
title: Clathrus columnatus

text: It may have been introduced to North America with exotic plants.
title: Clathrus columnatus

text: Similar to other stinkhorn fungi, the fruiting body, known as the "receptaculum", starts out as a subterranean "egg" form.
title: Clathrus columnatus

text: As the fungus develops, the receptaculum expands and erupts out of the protective volva, ultimately developing into mature structures characterized by two to five long vertical orange or red spongy columns, joined together at the apex.
title: Clathrus columnatus

text: The fully grown receptaculum reaches heights of 8 cm tall.
title: Clathrus columnatus

text: The inside surfaces of the columns are covered with a fetid olive-brown spore-containing slime, which attracts flies and other insects that help disseminate the spores.
title: Clathrus columnatus

text: Although once considered undesirable, the fungus is listed as edible.
title: Clathrus columnatus

text: It is found commonly in mulch.
title: Clathrus columnatus

text: BY1 is a taxnomically unidentified basidiomycete fungus.
title: BY1

text: ITS sequecing has placed it in the Russulales and is referred to as a stereaceous basidiomycete.
title: BY1

text: Chemotaxonomically supporting its placement in this group, it produces famonnoxins and vibralactones.
title: BY1

text: The fungus' mycelia was isolated from dead aspen in Minnesota, USA.
title: BY1

text: It is presumed to decompose wood by white rot .
title: BY1

text: Boletus edulis (English: penny bun, cep, porcino or porcini) is a basidiomycete fungus, and the type species of the genus "Boletus".
title: Boletus edulis

text: Widely distributed in the Northern Hemisphere across Europe, Asia, and North America, it does not occur naturally in the Southern Hemisphere, although it has been introduced to southern Africa, Australia, and New Zealand.
title: Boletus edulis

text: Several closely related European mushrooms formerly thought to be varieties or forms of "B. edulis" have been shown using molecular phylogenetic analysis to be distinct species, and others previously classed as separate species are conspecific with this species.
title: Boletus edulis

text: The western North American species commonly known as the California king bolete ("Boletus edulis" var.
title: Boletus edulis

text: "grandedulis") is a large, darker-coloured variant first formally identified in 2007.
title: Boletus edulis

text: Amanita excelsa" var.
title: Amanita excelsa var. spissa

text: "spissa is a variety of basidiomycete fungus of the genus "Amanita".
title: Amanita excelsa var. spissa

text: This large, grey to brown-capped fungus has a very variable appearance but is commonly encountered in coniferous and deciduous forests in Europe and North America.
title: Amanita excelsa var. spissa

text: It is sometimes referred to by the common name grey spotted Amanita.
title: Amanita excelsa var. spissa

text: Stereum ostrea, also called false turkey-tail and golden curtain crust, is a basidiomycete fungus in the genus "Stereum".
title: Stereum ostrea

text: It is a plant pathogen and a wood decay fungus.
title: Stereum ostrea

text: The name "ostrea", from the word 'oyster', describes its shape.
title: Stereum ostrea

text: Conocybe apala is a basidiomycete fungus and a member of "Conocybe".
title: Conocybe apala

text: It is a fairly common fungus, both in North America and Europe, found growing among short green grass.
title: Conocybe apala

text: Until recently, the species was also commonly called Conocybe lactea or Conocybe albipes and is colloquially known as the White Dunce Cap .
title: Conocybe apala

text: Another common synonym, "Bolbitius albipes" G.H. Otth 1871, places the fungus in the genus "Bolbitius".
title: Conocybe apala

text: Armillaria mellea, commonly known as honey fungus, is a basidiomycete fungus in the genus "Armillaria".
title: Armillaria mellea

text: It is a plant pathogen and part of a cryptic species complex of closely related and morphologically similar species.
title: Armillaria mellea

text: It causes Armillaria root rot in many plant species and produces mushrooms around the base of trees it has infected.
title: Armillaria mellea

text: The symptoms of infection appear in the crowns of infected trees as discoloured foliage, reduced growth, dieback of the branches and death.
title: Armillaria mellea

text: The mushrooms are edible but some people may be intolerant to them.
title: Armillaria mellea

text: This species is capable of producing light via bioluminescence in its mycelium.
title: Armillaria mellea

text: Bruce Rowland (born May 9, 1942 in Melbourne) is a well-known Australian composer.
title: Bruce Rowland

text: He composed the soundtrack for the 1982 movie "The Man from Snowy River", as well as the soundtrack for its 1988 sequel "The Man from Snowy River II" (which has the United States title of "Return to Snowy River", and the United Kingdom title of "The Untamed").
title: Bruce Rowland

text: Both films were based on Banjo Paterson's poem The Man from Snowy River.
title: Bruce Rowland

text: His other film scores include "Now and Forever" (1983), "Phar Lap" (1983), "Bushfire Moon" (1987), "Cheetah" (1989), "Weekend with Kate" (1990), "Gross Misconduct" (1993), "Andre" (1994), "Lightning Jack" (1994), "Zeus and Roxanne" (1997) and the TV movie "" (1997).
title: Bruce Rowland

text: "The Man from Snowy River is the original motion picture soundtrack from the 1982 film "The Man from Snowy River".
title: The Man from Snowy River (soundtrack)

text: Dangal (English: "Wrestling competition" ) is a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film loosely based on the story of Mahavir Singh Phogat, an amateur wrestler, who trains his daughters Geeta Phogat and Babita Kumari to be world-class wrestlers.
title: Dangal (film)

text: It was directed by Nitesh Tiwari.
title: Dangal (film)

text: Produced by Walt Disney Pictures, Aamir Khan Productions and UTV Motion Pictures, it stars Aamir Khan as the father.
title: Dangal (film)

text: Both daughters go on to win medals at the 2010 Commonwealth Games.
title: Dangal (film)

text: Babita won a silver medal at the Games, in the 51 kg class and gold at the 2014 Glasgow Games in the 55 kg class.
title: Dangal (film)

text: In 2012, Geeta became the first Indian female wrestler to qualify for the Olympics.
title: Dangal (film)

text: Mahavir's efforts inspired dozens of Indian women to take to wrestling.
title: Dangal (film)

text: Fatima Sana Shaikh and Sanya Malhotra play the older selves of the sisters while Sakshi Tanwar plays their mother and Aparshakti Khurana, their cousin.
title: Dangal (film)

text: Return to Snowy River is the original motion picture soundtrack from the 1988 film "The Man from Snowy River II".
title: Return to Snowy River

text: The soundtrack album is named after the American title for the film.
title: Return to Snowy River

text: The Barry Way is a partly unsealed alpine road running from Jindabyne southwest to the Victorian border, where it becomes the Snowy River Road.
title: Barry Way

text: It eventually leads to Buchan, a total distance of 170 kilometres with no services or towns.
title: Barry Way

text: It is sealed for the first 27 kilometres from Jindabyne, becoming unsealed at Ingebirah Gap, remaining so as far as the Victorian border.
title: Barry Way

text: The road passes through some very remote and unspoilt wilderness in the Australian Alps.
title: Barry Way

text: The scenery along the road provides views of the Snowy River valley and the surrounding mountains.
title: Barry Way

text: There are a number of campsites along the road, from Jacobs River southwards.
title: Barry Way

text: During the summer months, the weather on the Barry Way can be extremely hot and the sun's rays powerful whilst in winter the road can be closed for considerable amounts of time due to heavy snowfalls and dangerous ice.
title: Barry Way

text: At the NSW/VIC border, the Barry Way becomes known as Snowy River Road and continues southward into the Gippsland region of Victoria.
title: Barry Way

text: "The Man from Snowy River" is a poem by Australian bush poet Banjo Paterson.
title: The Man from Snowy River (poem)

text: It was first published in "The Bulletin", an Australian news magazine, on 26 April 1890, and was published by Angus & Robertson in October 1895, with other poems by Paterson, in "The Man from Snowy River and Other Verses".
title: The Man from Snowy River (poem)

text: The Man from Snowy River and Other Verses (1895) is the first collection of poems by Australian poet Banjo Paterson.
title: The Man from Snowy River and Other Verses

text: It was released in hardback by Angus and Robertson in 1895, and features the poet's widely anthologised poems "The Man from Snowy River", "Clancy of the Overflow", "Saltbush Bill" and "The Man from Ironbark".
title: The Man from Snowy River and Other Verses

text: It also contains the poet's first two poems that featured in The Bulletin Debate, a famous dispute in "The Bulletin" magazine from 1892-93 between Paterson and Henry Lawson.
title: The Man from Snowy River and Other Verses

text: The Man from Snowy River II is a 1988 Australian drama film, the sequel to the 1982 film "The Man from Snowy River".
title: The Man from Snowy River II

text: The Man from Snowy River is an Australian adventure drama television series based on Banjo Paterson's poem "The Man from Snowy River".
title: The Man from Snowy River (TV series)

text: Released in Australia as "Banjo Paterson's The Man from Snowy River", the series was subsequently released in both the United States and the United Kingdom as "Snowy River: The McGregor Saga".
title: The Man from Snowy River (TV series)

text: The Man from Snowy River is a 1982 Australian drama film based on the Banjo Paterson poem "The Man from Snowy River".
title: The Man from Snowy River (1982 film)

text: The film had a cast including Kirk Douglas in a dual role as the brothers Harrison (a character who appeared frequently in Paterson's poems) and Spur, Jack Thompson as Clancy, Tom Burlinson as Jim Craig, Sigrid Thornton as Harrison's daughter Jessica, Terence Donovan as Jim's father Henry Craig, and Chris Haywood as Curly.
title: The Man from Snowy River (1982 film)

text: Valencia CF had a successful season, finishing in the top four of La Liga and thus qualifying for the UEFA Champions League for the first time in almost 30 years, thanks to the extension of the competition to include more teams from the top leagues.
title: 1998–99 Valencia CF season

text: Valencia also won the Copa del Rey, ending a long trophy drought and marking a successful end to Italian coach Claudio Ranieri's first spell at the club.
title: 1998–99 Valencia CF season

text: Among the main players behind the success included Gaizka Mendieta, Javier Farinós and lethal striker Claudio López.
title: 1998–99 Valencia CF season

text: Mariano Alejandro Campodónico (born 4 May 1974) is a retired Argentine footballer forward who last played for Cañuelas.
title: Mariano Campodónico

text: He is the brother of current footballer Pablo Campodónico.
title: Mariano Campodónico

text: Luis Artime (born 2 December 1938 in Parque Civit in Mendoza Province) is a retired Argentine footballer, who played as a striker, and scored more than 1000 goals during his career.
title: Luis Artime

text: His son Luis Fabián Artime is also a retired Argentine footballer who played in the 1990s.
title: Luis Artime

text: This is a list of seasons played by Valencia CF Femenino, the women's section of Spanish football club Valencia CF, and its predecessor DSV Colegio Alemán.
title: List of Valencia CF Femenino seasons

text: The team was created in its original form in 1998, and has represented Valencia CF since the 2009–10 season.
title: List of Valencia CF Femenino seasons

title: 2002–03 Valencia CF season

text: "Los Che" also got to the quarter finals of the UEFA Champions League, where former coach Héctor Cúper and Inter got the upper hand over Valencia and Rafael Benítez.
title: 2002–03 Valencia CF season

text: The main player during the season was Pablo Aimar, who was the only player making waves in the season, where the previously solid defense did not perform as previously.
title: 2002–03 Valencia CF season

text: Mario Alberto Kempes Chiodi (born 15 July 1954 in Bell Ville, Córdoba) is a retired Argentine footballer who played as a striker.
title: Mario Kempes

text: His father, Mario, also a footballer, inspired him to play from a young age.
title: Mario Kempes

text: At the age of seven he began playing with a junior team and at fourteen, he joined the Talleres reserves.
title: Mario Kempes

text: A prolific goalscorer, at club level he is best known for playing for Valencia, finishing as La Liga's top goalscorer twice, and amassing 116 goals in 184 league games for the club.
title: Mario Kempes

text: Higinio Ortúzar Santamaria (10 January 1915 - 8 November 1982) is a retired Chilean footballer who played in Spain for Barakaldo CF, Athletic Bilbao, Valencia CF and Real Valladolid.
title: Higinio Ortúzar

text: After retiring as a player, he became a football coach, and managed sides including CD Logroñés.
title: Higinio Ortúzar

text: José Daniel Valencia (born 3 October 1955 in San Salvador, Jujuy Province) is a retired Argentine footballer, who played as an attacking midfielder.
title: José Daniel Valencia

text: He is perhaps most famous for having been part of the 1978 World Cup winning squad.
title: José Daniel Valencia

text: Claudio Javier López (] , born 17 July 1974) is a retired Argentine footballer who played as a forward.
title: Claudio López (footballer)
