text: The tournament was age-restricted and open to men's under-23 national teams only.
title: Men's football at the 2015 Pacific Games

text: The 2015 Pacific Games was held in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea, from 4 to 18 July 2015.
title: 2015 Pacific Games

text: It was the fifteenth staging of the Pacific Games.
title: 2015 Pacific Games

text: The Kiribati national basketball team are the basketball side that represent Kiribati in international competitions.
title: Kiribati national basketball team

text: They competed at the 2015 Pacific Games, where they finished with an 0-4 record.
title: Kiribati national basketball team

text: The Vanuatu national under-23 football team, also known as Vanuatu Cyclone, represents Vanuatu at U23 tournaments.
title: Vanuatu national under-23 football team

text: The team is considered to be the feeder team for the Vanuatu national football team.
title: Vanuatu national under-23 football team

text: They are controlled by the Vanuatu Football Federation.
title: Vanuatu national under-23 football team

text: The team has gained notoriety for thrashing Micronesia's side 46–0 in the 2015 Pacific Games.
title: Vanuatu national under-23 football team

text: Australia competed at the 2015 Pacific Games in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea from 4 to 18 July 2015.
title: Australia at the 2015 Pacific Games

text: Australia qualified 43 athletes.
title: Australia at the 2015 Pacific Games

text: It was the first time that Australia has competed in the Pacific Games.
title: Australia at the 2015 Pacific Games

text: William Morton was an English footballer who played as a centre forward.
title: William Morton (footballer)

text: Most likely born in Northumberland, he played the majority of his career in local-league football but also had spells in The Football League.
title: William Morton (footballer)

text: Morton played for Bedlington P.M. and Newbiggin West End before joining Third Division North side Durham City in 1927.
title: William Morton (footballer)

text: However, he was unable to break into the first-team and did not make a senior appearance for the club.
title: William Morton (footballer)

text: He left Durham the following year and returned to non-League football with Craghead United.
title: William Morton (footballer)

text: In January 1929, Morton was signed by Third Division North outfit Nelson, initially as an amateur.
title: William Morton (footballer)

text: He scored twice on his debut in the 4–1 win against Stockport County on 22 January and was awarded a professional contract the following month.
title: William Morton (footballer)

text: He went on to score three goals in eight League appearances for Nelson, but he was unable to displace Bernard Radford as the club's first-choice centre forward, and was not retained at the end of the 1928–29 season.
title: William Morton (footballer)

text: Milton Keynes Dons Football Club (usually abbreviated to MK Dons) is a professional association football club based in Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire, England, founded in 2004.
title: List of Milton Keynes Dons F.C. seasons

text: The club was formed from Wimbledon F.C. after the latter had relocated to Milton Keynes.
title: List of Milton Keynes Dons F.C. seasons

text: The club renamed itself as the 'Milton Keynes Dons' but subsequently considers itself to be a new club founded in 2004 (the club badge includes MMIV - Roman Numerals for 2004).
title: List of Milton Keynes Dons F.C. seasons

text: They continued in Wimbledon's league place which, after relegation in the previous season, was in the 2004–05 Football League One.
title: List of Milton Keynes Dons F.C. seasons

text: After two seasons in the third tier of English football they were relegated to the fourth tier (League Two).
title: List of Milton Keynes Dons F.C. seasons

text: They were promoted in their second League Two season, as champions.
title: List of Milton Keynes Dons F.C. seasons

text: Their second spell in League One lasted seven seasons, when in 2015, they finished in second place and therefore moved up to the Football League Championship.
title: List of Milton Keynes Dons F.C. seasons

text: However in 2016, they were relegated back down to League One.
title: List of Milton Keynes Dons F.C. seasons

text: Millwall Football Club ( ) is a professional football club in Bermondsey, South East London, England.
title: Millwall F.C.

text: The team competes in The Championship, the second tier of English football.
title: Millwall F.C.

text: Founded as Millwall Rovers in 1885, the club has retained its name despite having last played in the Millwall area of the Isle of Dogs in 1910.
title: Millwall F.C.

text: From then until 1993 the club played at what is now called The Old Den in New Cross, before moving to its current home stadium nearby, called The Den.
title: Millwall F.C.

text: The traditional club crest is a lion rampant, referred to in the team's nickname "The Lions".
title: Millwall F.C.

text: Millwall's traditional kit consists of blue shirts, white shorts and blue socks.
title: Millwall F.C.

text: Nogometni Klub Branik Maribor (English: Branik Maribor Football Club ), known as NK Branik or simply Branik, was an association football club based in the city of Maribor.
title: NK Branik Maribor

text: Founded on 29 January 1949 they traced their origin back to 1919 and the establishment of I. SSK Maribor (Slovene: "1.
title: NK Branik Maribor

text: Slovenski Športni Klub Maribor" , English: 1.
title: NK Branik Maribor

text: Slovene Sports Club Maribor ), an association football club founded by Slovenian youth which ceased all operations due to World War II.
title: NK Branik Maribor

text: NK Branik was disbanded on 11 August 1960 due to the food poisoning affair before their promotional qualifications match for the Yugoslav Second League against Karlovac.
title: NK Branik Maribor

text: The club colours were black and white.
title: NK Branik Maribor

text: Yarraville Football Club was an Australian rules football club founded in 1903 and played in the VJFA until 1927.
title: Yarraville Football Club

text: In 1928, the club joined the Victorian Football Association where it played until 1984 when the club went into recess.
title: Yarraville Football Club

text: In 1996, the Kingsville Football Club in the Western Region Football League who by this time had taken over the Yarraville ground changed their name to Yarraville.
title: Yarraville Football Club

text: In 2007 the Yarraville Football Club merged with the Seddon Football Club to become the Yarraville Seddon Eagles.
title: Yarraville Football Club

text: Walter Otto Davis (29 September 1888 – 20 May 1937) was a Welsh professional footballer who played at centre forward for Millwall for ten years in the 1910s.
title: Walter Davis (footballer)

text: He also made five appearances for the Welsh national team.
title: Walter Davis (footballer)

text: Robert Nuttall (1 May 1908 – 10 January 1983) was an English footballer who played as a winger or as a centre forward during his carer.
title: Robert Nuttall

text: Born in Tottington, Lancashire, he began his playing career with his hometown club before joining Football League Third Division North side Nelson in February 1931.
title: Robert Nuttall

text: One of Nelson's final signings as a League club, Nuttall made his debut at left-half in the 2–5 defeat to York City on 21 March 1931.
title: Robert Nuttall

text: He played as a centre forward in the team's following match, a 0–3 defeat away at Rotherham United.
title: Robert Nuttall

text: After two games out of the side, he returned for the 1–3 defeat against Wigan Borough.
title: Robert Nuttall

text: Nuttall made his final Football League appearance on the penultimate match of the 1930–31 season, the 1–5 loss to Wrexham on 25 April 1931.
title: Robert Nuttall

text: At the end of the campaign, Nelson failed their re-election to the League and subsequently joined the Lancashire Combination.
title: Robert Nuttall

text: Fudbalski klub Sarajevo (English: Sarajevo Football Club ) is a Bosnian professional football club based in Sarajevo, the capital city of Bosnia and Herzegovina and is one of the most successful clubs in the country.
title: FK Sarajevo

text: Founded on 24 October 1946, FK Sarajevo was the most successful club from SR Bosnia in former SFR Yugoslavia, winning two Yugoslav First League titles, being runners-up on two other occasions and finishing 6th in that competition's all-time table.
title: FK Sarajevo

text: The club's official colours are maroon and white.
title: FK Sarajevo

text: FK Sarajevo was the only major football club founded by the post-war Yugoslav authorities in the city of Sarajevo.
title: FK Sarajevo

text: The club entered the Yugoslav First League in the 1948–49 season, and eventually competed in all but two seasons in the top tier.
title: FK Sarajevo

text: After Bosnia and Herzegovina gained independence from Yugoslavia, FK Sarajevo became one the country's biggest ambassadors, departing on a large world tour during the Bosnian war with the goal of gaining international support for the country's cause.
title: FK Sarajevo

text: Thomas Pickering (born 1906, date of death unknown) was an English professional footballer who played as a centre forward.
title: Tom Pickering

text: Born in Egremont, Cumberland, he started his career playing local league football with his hometown club, before joining Football League Third Division North side Nelson as an amateur on 1 January 1927.
title: Tom Pickering

text: He made his debut for the club on the same day, deputising for the injured regular centre forward Jimmy Hampson in the 3–0 win against Wrexham at Seedhill.
title: Tom Pickering

text: Pickering was awarded a professional contract five days later, and remained at Nelson for a further two months but he did not make another senior appearance for the Lancashire club and returned to Egremont in March 1927.
title: Tom Pickering

text: His stay was brief, however, as he transferred to nearby Parton Athletic in the summer of the same year.
title: Tom Pickering

text: King's College Hospital RFC is an open rugby union club founded in the 19th century as a football club whose representatives were made up of medics from King's College Hospital.
title: King's College Hospital RFC

text: In its original form it was one of the twenty-one founding members of the Rugby Football Union, and produced a number of international players in the sport's early international fixtures.
title: King's College Hospital RFC

text: The merging of King's College Hospital medical department in 1999 with the already merged Guy's Hospital and St Thomas' Hospital led to the creation of Guy's, Kings and St. Thomas' Rugby Football Club, an amalgam of three formerly distinct hospital rugby clubs each with a long history.
title: King's College Hospital RFC

text: King's College Hospital Rugby Football Club opted to remain a separate entity in so doing became an open rugby club that no longer represented the Hospital medics.
title: King's College Hospital RFC

text: Randy Roth is a convicted murderer and thief from Washington.
title: Randy Roth

text: He was convicted of the 1991 murder of his fourth wife, Cynthia Baumgartner Roth.
title: Randy Roth

text: He was suspected but never tried for murdering his second wife, Janis Roth, in 1981.
title: Randy Roth

text: In both deaths he was the only witness, he claimed the activity that led to the death was the idea of his deceased wife, and the bodies were cremated as quickly as could be arranged.
title: Randy Roth

text: He was also convicted of stealing in the form of defrauding insurers and the Social Security Administration and was sentenced to one year for theft and 50 years for first degree murder in 1992.
title: Randy Roth

text: At least two true crime books are based on Roth's crimes, "A Rose for Her Grave" by Ann Rule and "Fatal Charm" by Carlton Smith.
title: Randy Roth

text: "School Boy Crush" is a song from Average White Band's 1975 album, "Cut the Cake".
title: School Boy Crush

text: The song is not to be confused with "Schoolboy Crush", which was recorded by American pop singer Bobby Helms, and also UK rocker Cliff Richard as the B-side to his hit "Move It".
title: School Boy Crush

text: "Halftime" is the 1992 debut single by American rapper Nas, released under his original moniker of Nasty Nas.
title: Halftime (song)

text: It was originally recorded for the "Zebrahead" soundtrack album, released October 13, 1992, on Ruffhouse Records.
title: Halftime (song)

text: "Halftime" was produced by Large Professor and features samples from "Schoolboy Crush" by Average White Band, "Soul Traveling" by Gary Byrd, and "Dead End" by Japanese Hair.
title: Halftime (song)

text: The song was later included on Nas' influential 1994 debut album, "Illmatic".
title: Halftime (song)

text: Schoolboy Crush (2004) is a controversial gay pornographic film directed by Bryan Kocis (under the industry name "Bryan Phillips"), released on Cobra Video, and cast with Brent Everett and Sean Paul Lockhart under the stage name "Brent Corrigan".
title: Schoolboy Crush (film)

text: Corrigan being underage at the time of filming led to legal actions against Phillips and the withdrawal of the film "Schoolboy Crush" from the Cobra Video film catalog.
title: Schoolboy Crush (film)

text: Edward William Pritchard (6 December 1825 – 28 July 1865) was an English doctor who was convicted of murdering his wife and mother-in-law by poisoning them.
title: Edward William Pritchard

text: He was also suspected of murdering a servant girl, but was never tried for this crime.
title: Edward William Pritchard

text: Bryan Charles Kocis (May 28, 1962 – January 24, 2007), also known as Bryan Phillips, was a director of gay pornographic films and founder of Cobra Video, a gay porn film studio.
title: Bryan Kocis

text: Kocis was murdered at his Dallas Township, Pennsylvania home on January 24, 2007; arson was used in an attempt to disguise the circumstances of his death.
title: Bryan Kocis

text: Two escorts, Harlow Cuadra and Joseph Kerekes, were charged and convicted for Kocis' murder and subsequently given a sentence of life imprisonment without any possibility of parole.
title: Bryan Kocis

text: "Move It" is a song written by Ian Samwell and recorded by Cliff Richard and the Drifters (the UK band that would evolve into The Shadows).
title: Move It

text: Originally intended as the B-side to "Schoolboy Crush", it was released as Richard's debut single on 29 August 1958 and became his first hit record, reaching no.2 on the UK singles chart.
title: Move It

text: It is credited with being one of the first authentic rock and roll songs produced outside the United States.
title: Move It

text: Isaac Bledsoe Desha (January 1, 1802 – August 13, 1828) was a 19th-century American tanner who was convicted of murdering one man in Kentucky, and confessed to murdering another in Texas.
title: Isaac B. Desha

text: He was notable as the son of the Kentucky Governor, Joseph Desha.
title: Isaac B. Desha

text: Shortly after his father's election as governor in 1824, Desha was accused of robbing and killing a man named Francis Baker, who was passing through Kentucky.
title: Isaac B. Desha

text: Circumstantial evidence implicated Desha, who denied the crime.
title: Isaac B. Desha

text: Louise Peete (September 20, 1880 – April 11, 1947) was a convicted American murderer.
title: Louise Peete

text: Peete was first convicted of murdering wealthy mining engineer Jacob C. Denton in 1920 and was sentenced to life in prison.
title: Louise Peete

text: She was paroled in April 1939.
title: Louise Peete

text: In May 1945, she was convicted of murdering her employer, Margaret Logan, and sentenced to death.
title: Louise Peete

text: She was executed in April 1947 making her the second, and one of only four women, to be executed in the California gas chamber.
title: Louise Peete

text: Dena Thompson (born 1960) is a former confidence trickster and bigamist.
title: Dena Thompson

text: She habitually met men through lonely hearts columns and stole their money.
title: Dena Thompson

text: She is currently in prison for murdering former BT Manager Julian Webb.
title: Dena Thompson

text: She was acquitted of the attempted murder of a second man, Robert Thompson, and is also suspected of murdering an ex-boyfriend.
title: Dena Thompson

text: She was sentenced to 16 years in prison at the age of 43.
title: Dena Thompson

text: She was also convicted of stealing from and defrauding her former lovers.
title: Dena Thompson

text: Following her conviction Detective Chief Inspector Martyn Underhill, stated: "This woman is every man's nightmare, the most dangerous woman I have ever met.
title: Dena Thompson

text: For a decade, she has targeted men sexually, financially and physically.
title: Dena Thompson

text: The men of Britain can sleep safe tonight knowing she has been taken off the streets."
title: Dena Thompson

text: A judge described her as:
title: Dena Thompson

text: Eastman Kodak v Harold Worden is case of industrial espionage involving the sale of information by Harold Worden, a former Kodak manager, to Kodak's competitors in 1995.
title: Eastman Kodak Co v. Harold Worden

text: Worden was caught selling details on the 401 process, a process designed to increase the speed and quality of film during development, during a sting operation conducted by Kodak after two of their competitors, Konica and Agfa-Gevaert, told Kodak that he had approached them selling trade secrets.
title: Eastman Kodak Co v. Harold Worden

text: After the sting operation, Worden was sentenced to 15-month prison sentence and a fine of $30,000 for interstate transportation of stolen property.
title: Eastman Kodak Co v. Harold Worden

text: Aniruddha Bahal (born 1967) is an Indian journalist, author, founder and editor of the online magazine "Cobrapost.com".
title: Aniruddha Bahal

text: Born in Allahabad, Bahal worked as a journalist and editor for "India Today" and "Outlook".
title: Aniruddha Bahal

text: In 1999, he along with Tarun Tejpal co-founded "Tehelka", an investigative news website.
title: Aniruddha Bahal

text: While at Tehelka, Bahal conceived and carried out a sting operation which caught members of Indian Cricket Team accepting bribes to throw matches in camera.
title: Aniruddha Bahal

text: It resulted in a series of articles on match fixing in Indian Cricket, which were eventually published as a book -" Fallen Heroes".
title: Aniruddha Bahal

text: Bahal is also known for his part in Operation West End, another sting operation.
title: Aniruddha Bahal

text: In 2003, he left "Tehelka".
title: Aniruddha Bahal

text: Operation Duryodhana (2005) was the code name of a sting operation, which captured on camera eleven members of Parliament of India accepting money to table questions on the floor of the Parliament.
title: Operation Duryodhana

text: This was the first such sting operation in the history of Republic of India, and all the members were expelled from the Parliament.
title: Operation Duryodhana

text: It begins by telling the story of Operation Lunar Eclipse, the first successful sting operation to recover a piece of the moon brought back by American astronauts, a sting operation the professor led and went undercover in, while still an agent.
title: The Case of the Missing Moon Rocks

text: The sting operation successfully recovered the Honduras Apollo 17 Goodwill Moon Rock that was in the possession of Florida businessman Alan H. Rosen.
title: The Case of the Missing Moon Rocks

text: This operation was funded in part with the financial assistance of H. Ross Perot, billionaire and former Presidential candidate.
title: The Case of the Missing Moon Rocks

text: Abscam—sometimes written ABSCAM—was a Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) sting operation that took place in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
title: Abscam

text: The two-year investigation was directed from the FBI's office in Hauppauge, New York, and was under the supervision of Assistant Director Neil J. Welch, who headed the bureau's New York division, and Thomas P. Puccio, head of the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force for the Eastern District of New York.
title: Abscam

text: The operation initially targeted trafficking in stolen property and corruption of prestigious businessmen, but was later converted to a public corruption investigation.
title: Abscam

text: The FBI, aided by the Justice Department and a convicted con-man, videotaped politicians accepting bribes from a fraudulent Arabian company in return for various political favors.
title: Abscam

text: The Bribery and Special Interest (BRISPEC) sting operation was a sting operation conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation investigating corruption in the California State Legislature from 1986 to 1988.
title: BRISPEC sting operation

text: The operation was also known as Shrimpscam because FBI agents posed as representatives of a West Sacramento-based shrimp processing company who gave campaign contributions to law makers in exchange for favorable legislation to the front company.
title: BRISPEC sting operation

text: A couple of the bills were actually passed by both the Assembly and Senate, but were vetoed by Governor George Deukmejian, who was tipped off in advance.
title: BRISPEC sting operation

text: Evelyn Dawn Knight (born November 5, 1942) is an English woman known for her involvement in the Abscam sting operation of the 1970s, with her ex-husband Mel Weinberg.
title: Evelyn Knight

text: A character inspired by her was portrayed on film by Amy Adams in "American Hustle" (2013) for which Adams was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actress.
title: Evelyn Knight

text: The story of Abscam was depicted as well in the 1981 book "The Sting Man" by Robert Greene.
title: Evelyn Knight

text: The 2012 Indian Premier League spot-fixing case was a controversy which arose during the 2012 Indian Premier League and led to the banning of five cricketers.
title: 2012 Indian Premier League spot-fixing case

text: It started when a Hindi news channel, India TV, aired a sting operation which accused five players of seeking money in exchange for spot-fixing.
title: 2012 Indian Premier League spot-fixing case

text: Bans were imposed on all five, with a life-ban on Deccan Chargers's TP Sudhindra, a five-year ban on Kings XI Punjab's Shalabh Srivastava, and a one-year ban on Pune Warriors India's Mohnish Mishra and Kings XI Punjab's Amit Yadav.
title: 2012 Indian Premier League spot-fixing case

text: In addition Abhinav Bali, who was not in contact with any team during the 2012 season, was banned for a year.
title: 2012 Indian Premier League spot-fixing case

text: In the sting operation, Bali claimed to have spot-fixed during the 2009 season.
title: 2012 Indian Premier League spot-fixing case

text: According to the sting operation, some of the players revealed that they had received more money from the franchises' owners than agreed on in the players' auction; they said that this money was black money.
title: 2012 Indian Premier League spot-fixing case

text: Operation Bittersweet was a sting operation in the 1980s in which the U.S. Department of Justice caught companies illegally importing sugar from foreign countries in violation of the U.S. Customs Service's 1984 restrictions on the importation of sugar products.
title: Operation Bittersweet

text: The sting resulted in 30 companies being implicated and over $16 million USD in fines.
title: Operation Bittersweet

text: The Narada sting operation was a sting operation carried out by Mathew Samuel in 2011 for the Indian newsmagazine "Tehelka" and published in Naradanews.com just before the 2016 West Bengal Assembly elections.
title: Narada sting operation

text: The sting targeted high-ranking officials and politicians of All India Trinamul Congress (AITC).
title: Narada sting operation

text: As of June 2017, the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) and a parliamentary ethics committee are probing the case.
title: Narada sting operation

text: The Trinamool Congress, has claimed that the money was received in way of donations.
title: Narada sting operation

text: The Grudge is a 2004 American supernatural horror film and a remake of the Japanese film, "".
title: The Grudge

text: The film was released in North America on October 22, 2004, by Columbia Pictures, and was directed by Takashi Shimizu (director of all previous "Ju-on" films) while Stephen Susco scripted the film.
title: The Grudge

text: The plot is told through a non-linear sequence of events and includes several intersecting subplots.
title: The Grudge

text: The film was a box office success, making over $187 million against a $10 million budget, though it received only mixed reviews from critics.
title: The Grudge

text: The Grudge 2 is a 2006 American supernatural horror film and a sequel to the 2004 film, "The Grudge".
title: The Grudge 2

text: Produced by Sam Raimi, the film was directed by Takashi Shimizu (director of the "Ju-on" series), written by Stephen Susco and stars an ensemble cast that includes Amber Tamblyn, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Edison Chen, Arielle Kebbel, Jenna Dewan Tatum, Teresa Palmer, Misako Uno, Matthew Knight and Takako Fuji.
title: The Grudge 2

title: Rafoo Chakkar

text: Red is a 2008 thriller film based on a novel by Jack Ketchum and directed by Trygve Allister Diesen and Lucky McKee.

title: Red (2008 film)

text: Samuel M "Sam" Raimi ( ; born October 23, 1959) is an American film director, producer, screenwriter and actor, famous for creating the cult horror "Evil Dead" series, as well as directing the original "Spider-Man" trilogy (2002–07), the 1990 superhero film "Darkman" and the "I Will Rip Your Soul Out" scene from the 2013 remake of "Evil Dead".

title: Beyond the Reach

text: Texas Chainsaw (promoted as Texas Chainsaw 3D) is a 2013 American slasher film directed by John Luessenhop, with a screenplay by Adam Marcus, Debra Sullivan and Kirsten Elms and a story by Stephen Susco, Marcus and Sullivan.
title: Texas Chainsaw 3D

text: It is the seventh installment in "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" franchise and was presented in 3-D.

text: The film stars Alexandra Daddario, Dan Yeager, Trey Songz, Tania Raymonde, Scott Eastwood, Thom Barry, Paul Rae and Bill Moseley, with Gunnar Hansen and Marilyn Burns, who had appeared in the original 1974 film.

text: Stephen Susco is an American film and television screenwriter who is most famous for writing the hit movies "The Grudge" and "The Grudge 2".
title: Stephen Susco

title: The Grudge 3

title: The Grudge 3

text: The film stars Johanna Braddy, Shawnee Smith and Marina Sirtis, with a special appearance by Matthew Knight (from "The Grudge 2"), and was released on DVD on May 12, 2009.

text: Love & Friendship is a 2016 period comedy film written and directed by Whit Stillman.
title: Love & Friendship

text: Based on Jane Austen's epistolary novel "Lady Susan", written ca. 1794, the film stars Kate Beckinsale, Chloë Sevigny, Xavier Samuel, and Stephen Fry.
title: Love & Friendship

text: The film follows recently widowed Lady Susan in her intrepid and calculating exploits to secure suitably wealthy husbands for her daughter and herself.
title: Love & Friendship

text: Although adapted from "Lady Susan", the film was produced under the borrowed title of Austen's juvenile story "Love and Freindship" ["sic"] .
title: Love & Friendship

text: "The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons" is the seventh episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> ninth season.
title: The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons

text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on November 16, 1997.
title: The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons

text: It was written by Richard Appel and directed by Steven Dean Moore.
title: The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons

text: The episode sees Apu Nahasapeemapetilon marry Manjula, and incorporates several aspects of Hindu wedding ceremonies, which the writers researched during the episode's production.
title: The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons

text: Appel pitched the episode several years before season nine but the idea was not used until Mike Scully became showrunner.
title: The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons

text: The episode's subplot, which sees Homer stay at the Springfield Retirement Castle, was initially conceived as a separate episode, but could not be developed in enough detail.
title: The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons

text: The episode received mixed reviews.
title: The Two Mrs. Nahasapeemapetilons

text: "Realty Bites" is the ninth episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> ninth season.
title: Realty Bites

text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on December 7, 1997.
title: Realty Bites

text: The episode sees Marge becoming a real estate agent, while Homer enjoys Snake's car.
title: Realty Bites

text: It was written by Dan Greaney and directed by Swinton O. Scott III.
title: Realty Bites

text: "Lost Our Lisa" is the twenty-fourth episode in the ninth season of the American animated television series "The Simpsons".
title: Lost Our Lisa

text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on May 10, 1998.
title: Lost Our Lisa

text: The episode contains the last appearance of the character Lionel Hutz.
title: Lost Our Lisa

text: When Lisa learns that Marge cannot give her a ride to the museum and forbids her to take the bus, she tricks Homer into giving her permission.
title: Lost Our Lisa

text: After Lisa gets lost, Homer goes looking for her and the two end up visiting the museum together.
title: Lost Our Lisa

text: The episode is analyzed in the books "Planet Simpson", "The Psychology of the Simpsons: D'oh!
title: Lost Our Lisa

text: ", and "", and received positive mention in "I Can't Believe It's a Bigger and Better Updated Unofficial Simpsons Guide".
title: Lost Our Lisa

text: Lionel Hutz is a fictional character in the animated television series "The Simpsons".
title: Lionel Hutz

text: He was voiced by Phil Hartman, and his first appearance was in the season two episode "Bart Gets Hit by a Car".
title: Lionel Hutz

text: Hutz is a stereotypical ambulance chasing lawyer in Springfield with questionable competence and ethics.
title: Lionel Hutz

text: He is nevertheless (or thus) often hired by the Simpsons.
title: Lionel Hutz

text: Following Hartman's murder in 1998, Hutz was retired out of respect; and his final speaking role was in the season nine episode "Realty Bites" five months earlier.
title: Lionel Hutz

text: "Bart Gets Hit by a Car" is the tenth episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> second season.
title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car

text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on January 10, 1991.
title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car

text: At the start of the episode, Bart is hit by Mr. Burns<nowiki>'</nowiki> car.
title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car

text: Prompted by ambulance-chasing lawyer Lionel Hutz and quack doctor Dr. Nick Riviera, the Simpsons sue Mr. Burns, seeking extensive damages for Bart's injuries.
title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car

text: Hutz and Dr. Nick exaggerate Bart's injuries so they can gain sympathy at the trial.
title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car

text: Marge is against the whole thing and grows concerned with the fact that Homer is asking Bart to lie.
title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car

text: Abraham Lincoln, also released under the title D. W. Griffith's "Abraham Lincoln", is a 1930 Pre-Code biographical film about American president Abraham Lincoln directed by D. W. Griffith.
title: Abraham Lincoln (1930 film)

text: It stars Walter Huston as Lincoln and Una Merkel, in her second speaking role, as Ann Rutledge.
title: Abraham Lincoln (1930 film)

text: Her first speaking role was in a short film, "Love's Old Sweet Song" (1923) filmed in the Phonofilm sound-on-film process.
title: Abraham Lincoln (1930 film)

text: The script was co-written by Stephen Vincent Benét and Gerrit Lloyd, author of the Civil War prose poem "John Brown's Body".
title: Abraham Lincoln (1930 film)

text: This was the first of only two sound films made by Griffith.
title: Abraham Lincoln (1930 film)

text: Season nine of "Smallville", an American television series, began airing on September 25, 2009.
title: Smallville (season 9)

text: The series recounts the early adventures of Kryptonian Clark Kent as he adjusts to life in the fictional town of Smallville, Kansas, during the years before he becomes Superman.
title: Smallville (season 9)

text: The ninth season comprises 21 episodes and concluded its initial airing on May 14, 2010, marking the fourth season to air on The CW television network.
title: Smallville (season 9)

text: After four seasons broadcasting on Thursday nights at 8:00 pm, "Smallville" was moved to Friday nights at 8:00 pm for season nine, to make room for "The Vampire Diaries".
title: Smallville (season 9)

text: "The Day the Violence Died" is the eighteenth episode of "The Simpsons"' seventh season.
title: The Day the Violence Died

text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on March 17, 1996.
title: The Day the Violence Died

text: It was written by John Swartzwelder and directed by Wes Archer.
title: The Day the Violence Died

text: Kirk Douglas guest stars as Chester J. Lampwick, Alex Rocco as Roger Meyers Jr., Jack Sheldon as an anthropomorphic constitutional amendment, Suzanne Somers as herself, and Phil Hartman as Lionel Hutz.
title: The Day the Violence Died

text: The end of the episode features Lester and Eliza, versions of Bart and Lisa Simpson that appeared in "The Tracey Ullman Show" in the 1980s.
title: The Day the Violence Died

text: "Marge in Chains" is the 21st episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> fourth season.
title: Marge in Chains

text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on May 6, 1993.
title: Marge in Chains

text: In the episode, Marge is arrested for shoplifting after forgetting to pay for an item at the Kwik-E-Mart.
title: Marge in Chains

text: The family hires attorney Lionel Hutz to defend her at trial, but she is found guilty and sentenced to 30 days imprisonment.
title: Marge in Chains

text: Homer, and the rest of the family have trouble coping without Marge.
title: Marge in Chains

text: The townspeople start a riot when an annual bake sale missing Marge fails to raise enough money for a statue of Abraham Lincoln and they have to settle for a statue of Jimmy Carter.
title: Marge in Chains

text: Mayor Quimby has Marge released from jail in order to save his career and quell the riot.
title: Marge in Chains

text: "22 Short Films About Springfield" is the twenty-first episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> seventh season.
title: 22 Short Films About Springfield

text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on April 14, 1996.
title: 22 Short Films About Springfield

text: It was written by Richard Appel, David S. Cohen, Jonathan Collier, Jennifer Crittenden, Greg Daniels, Brent Forrester, Dan Greaney, Rachel Pulido, Steve Tompkins, Josh Weinstein, Bill Oakley, and Matt Groening, with the writing being supervised by Daniels.
title: 22 Short Films About Springfield

text: The episode was directed by Jim Reardon.
title: 22 Short Films About Springfield

text: Phil Hartman guest starred as Lionel Hutz and the hospital board chairman.
title: 22 Short Films About Springfield

text: The episode looks into the lives of other Springfield residents in a series of linked stories and originated from the end segment of the season four episode "The Front".
title: 22 Short Films About Springfield

text: The episode is a loose parody of "Pulp Fiction", which gave the staff the idea of a possible spin-off from "The Simpsons".
title: 22 Short Films About Springfield

text: The title is a reference to the film "Thirty Two Short Films About Glenn Gould".
title: 22 Short Films About Springfield

text: The episode received positive reviews from critics.
title: 22 Short Films About Springfield

text: "The Closer You Get" is a song recorded by American country music band Alabama.
title: The Closer You Get (song)

text: It was released in April 1983 as the title track and second single from Alabama's album "The Closer You Get...".
title: The Closer You Get (song)

text: Rivermaya is a Filipino rock band.
title: Rivermaya

text: Formed in 1994, it is one of several bands who spearheaded the 1990s Philippine alternative rock explosion.
title: Rivermaya

text: Rivermaya is currently composed of original members Mark Escueta and Nathan Azarcon, together with Mike Elgar and Ryan Peralta.
title: Rivermaya

text: Former original members include Rico Blanco, who had been the original songwriter of the band and vocalist Bamboo Mañalac, who later formed the band Bamboo and later went on his solo career.
title: Rivermaya

text: Rivermaya is listed as the twentieth biggest-selling artists/act in the Philippines as of present.
title: Rivermaya

text: "Honest" is a song by Dublin-based alternative rock quartet Kodaline.
title: Honest (Kodaline song)

text: The song was released on 1 February 2015 as the lead single from the band's second studio album, "Coming Up for Air" (2015).
title: Honest (Kodaline song)

text: "Honest" became the band's third top 10 single in their home country, Ireland, following "High Hopes" (2013) and "Love Like This" (2013).
title: Honest (Kodaline song)

text: Kid Confucius were an eight-piece Australian band from Sydney, Australia.
title: Kid Confucius

text: They formed in 2001 and have since played well over 400 live shows around the country, including major festivals as well as their own headline shows at venues such as The Annandale Hotel and The Metro Theatre.
title: Kid Confucius

text: In 2005 the band released a self-titled album and two singles "Words" and "Skintight."
title: Kid Confucius

text: The album, a mish-mash of soul, hip-hop, pop and funk, received great critical acclaim, most notably from Rolling Stone who hailed the album as one of the standout local releases of the year.
title: Kid Confucius

text: "Words" also enjoyed some solid months of radio and TV play.
title: Kid Confucius

text: The band released its second album Stripes in 2007 with three singles "Closer", "Last Straw" and "Moment".
title: Kid Confucius

text: Stripes was the band's attempt at making a Detroit-era Motown soul album and it was quick to earn rave reviews from press around the country as well as a publishing deal with Mushroom.
title: Kid Confucius

text: "Moment" has enjoyed good radio play on triple j. Kid Confucius is set to release its third album in October 2008.
title: Kid Confucius

text: The first single from this album, "Good Luck", is out now.
title: Kid Confucius

text: "Houston (Means I'm One Day Closer to You)" is a song written by Larry Gatlin and recorded by American country music group Larry Gatlin & the Gatlin Brothers Band.
title: Houston (Means I'm One Day Closer to You)

text: It was released in September 1983 as the first single from the album ""Greatest Hits Vol.
title: Houston (Means I'm One Day Closer to You)

text: II"" then included to first track of ""Not Guilty"" (1984).
title: Houston (Means I'm One Day Closer to You)

text: "Houston (Means I'm One Day Closer to You)" was the group's third and last number one on the country chart.
title: Houston (Means I'm One Day Closer to You)

text: The single went to number one for two weeks and spent a total of fifteen weeks on the country chart.
title: Houston (Means I'm One Day Closer to You)

text: Myron is a Swiss pop-rock duo based singing in English language and made up of lead singer Emanuel "Manu" Gut (also widely known by his stage name Manu-L) and songwriter, guitarist and bass player Chris Haffner.
title: Myron (duo)

text: The two met while working as studio musicians and they formed the band in 2003, in Basel, Switzerland.
title: Myron (duo)

text: The band signed with Columbia Records of Sony BMG in 2007, and has released four albums and a number of singles that charted in Switzerland, with the single "One Step Closer" being their biggest hit.
title: Myron (duo)

text: The duo's sound is primarily soft contemporary rock with a definite melodic twist, and soul and pop/country influences.
title: Myron (duo)

text: The duo that performs its concerts with a full live band including drummer, guitarist and keyboardist is signed to the Columbia Records label, part of Sony Music Entertainment.
title: Myron (duo)

text: The Closer You Get... is the seventh studio album by country music band Alabama, released in 1983.
title: The Closer You Get...

text: All three singles from this album — "The Closer You Get", "Lady Down on Love" and "Dixieland Delight" — reached Number One on the Hot Country Songs charts in 1983.
title: The Closer You Get...

text: "She Put the Sad in All His Songs" was also recorded by Ronnie Dunn (who formed the duo Brooks & Dunn with Kix Brooks in 1991) and was released by him as a single in 1983.
title: The Closer You Get...

text: Perfecto "Perf" de Castro (born August 14) is a multi-awarded Filipino musician, currently focusing on Classical and Flamenco music played on the Ten-string guitar, and now widely regarded being the best guitarist in the country.
title: Perfecto de Castro

text: but perhaps best known for having been a celebrated fixture in the Philippine alternative rock scene during the 1990s.
title: Perfecto de Castro

text: During the course of that decade, he was one of the original members of the alternative rock band Rivermaya, founded the band Triaxis, and also collaborated with the seminal Filipino rapper Francis Magalona and Filipino hard rock band Wolfgang.
title: Perfecto de Castro

text: The V.I.P.s were a British R&B musical ensemble formed in Carlisle, Cumberland, (North West England) in late 1963, out of an earlier outfit known as The Ramrods, who had formed in Carlisle in 1960.
title: The V.I.P.s (band)

text: After a change of personnel in April 1967, the band changed their name to "Art", and released the album "Supernatural Fairy Tales".
title: The V.I.P.s (band)

text: They also participated to a psychedelic bizarre album called "Featuring The Human Host And The Heavy Metal Kids" by a collective known as Hapshash and the Coloured Coat, formed by Guy Stevens and an influential British graphic design and avant-garde musical partnership between Michael English and Nigel Waymouth.
title: The V.I.P.s (band)

text: The musicians involved in that project were Mike Harrison on keys and vocals, Luther Grosvenor on guitars, Greg Ridley on bass and Mike Kellie on drums, as well as performances by Stevens, English and Waymouth.
title: The V.I.P.s (band)

text: It was the first time that the term "heavy metal" was ever used in music, even though that album had nothing to do with heavy metal music, being closer to psychedelic music.
title: The V.I.P.s (band)

text: That album was published in 1967 on Liberty Records and contained only five songs from two minutes to more than 15 minutes of psychedelic and almost meditative state kind of music.
title: The V.I.P.s (band)

text: Kodaline ( ) are an Irish band.
title: Kodaline

text: Originally known as 21 Demands, in 2012 the band changed their name to Kodaline.
title: Kodaline

text: The Allied invasion of Italy was the Allied amphibious landing on mainland Italy that took place on 3 September 1943 during the early stages of the Italian Campaign of World War II.
title: Allied invasion of Italy

text: The operation was undertaken by General Sir Harold Alexander's 15th Army Group (comprising General Mark W. Clark and General Bernard Montgomery's British Eighth Army) and followed the successful invasion of Sicily.
title: Allied invasion of Italy

text: The main invasion force landed around Salerno on 9 September on the western coast in Operation Avalanche, while two supporting operations took place in Calabria (Operation Baytown) and Taranto (Operation Slapstick).
title: Allied invasion of Italy

text: Operation "Ladbroke" was a glider landing by British airborne troops during the Second World War near Syracuse, Sicily, that began on 9 July 1943 as part of Operation Husky, the Allied invasion of Sicily.
title: Operation Ladbroke

text: The first Allied mission using large numbers of the aircraft, the operation was carried out from Tunisia by glider infantry of the British 1st Airlanding Brigade, commanded by Brigadier Philip Hicks, with a force of 136 Waco Hadrians and eight Airspeed Horsas.
title: Operation Ladbroke

text: The objective was to establish a large invasion force on the ground near the town of Syracuse, secure the Ponte Grande Bridge and ultimately take control of the city itself with its strategically vital docks, as a prelude to the full-scale invasion of Sicily.
title: Operation Ladbroke

text: Marshal of the Royal Air Force Arthur William Tedder, 1st Baron Tedder, {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (11 July 1890 – 3 June 1967) was a senior Royal Air Force commander.
title: Arthur Tedder, 1st Baron Tedder

text: He was a pilot and squadron commander in the Royal Flying Corps in the First World War and he went on to serve as a senior officer in the Royal Air Force during the inter-war years when he served in Turkey, Great Britain and the Far East.
title: Arthur Tedder, 1st Baron Tedder

text: During the Second World War, as Air Officer Commanding RAF Middle East Command, Tedder directed air operations in the Mediterranean and North Africa, including the evacuation of Crete and "Operation Crusader" in North Africa.
title: Arthur Tedder, 1st Baron Tedder

text: His bombing tactics became known as the "Tedder Carpet".
title: Arthur Tedder, 1st Baron Tedder

text: Later in the war Tedder took command of Mediterranean Air Command and in that role was closely involved in the planning of the Allied invasion of Sicily and then the Allied invasion of Italy.
title: Arthur Tedder, 1st Baron Tedder

text: When Operation Overlord—the invasion of France—came to be planned, Tedder was appointed Deputy Supreme Commander at Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force under General Eisenhower.
title: Arthur Tedder, 1st Baron Tedder

text: After the war he served as Chief of the Air Staff, in which role he advocated increased recruiting in the face of many airmen leaving the service, doubled the size of RAF Fighter Command and implemented arrangements for the Berlin Airlift in 1948.
title: Arthur Tedder, 1st Baron Tedder

text: After the war he held senior positions in business and academia.
title: Arthur Tedder, 1st Baron Tedder

text: Operation Corkscrew was the code name for the Allied invasion of the Italian island of Pantelleria (between Sicily and Tunisia) on 11 June 1943, prior to the Allied invasion of Sicily during the Second World War.
title: Operation Corkscrew

text: There had been an early plan to occupy the island in late 1940 (Operation Workshop), but this was aborted when the Luftwaffe strengthened the Axis air threat in the region.
title: Operation Corkscrew

text: Operation Citadel (German: "Unternehmen Zitadelle" ) was a German offensive operation against Soviet forces in the Kursk salient during the Second World War on the Eastern Front that initiated the Battle of Kursk.
title: Operation Citadel

text: The deliberate defensive operation that the Soviets implemented to repel the German offensive is referred to as the Kursk Strategic Defensive Operation.
title: Operation Citadel

text: The German offensive was countered by two Soviet counter-offensives, Operation Polkovodets Rumyantsev (Russian: Полководец Румянцев ) and Operation Kutuzov (Russian: Кутузов ).
title: Operation Citadel

text: For the Germans, the battle was the final strategic offensive that they were able to launch on the Eastern Front.
title: Operation Citadel

text: As the Allied invasion of Sicily began Adolf Hitler was forced to divert troops training in France to meet the Allied threats in the Mediterranean, rather than use them as a strategic reserve for the Eastern Front.
title: Operation Citadel

text: Germany's extensive loss of men and tanks ensured that the victorious Soviet Red Army enjoyed the strategic initiative for the remainder of the war.
title: Operation Citadel

text: The Man Who Never Was is a 1953 book by Ewen Montagu about the World War II Operation Mincemeat.
title: The Man Who Never Was (book)

text: Montagu played a leading role in the 1943 scheme to deceive the Germans about the planned Allied invasion of Sicily.
title: The Man Who Never Was (book)

text: Montagu's work formed the basis for a 1956 film by the same title.
title: The Man Who Never Was (book)

text: The scheme entailed releasing a dead body just off the coast of Spain, where strong currents caused it to drift ashore in an area where a skilled German secret agent was known to operate.
title: The Man Who Never Was (book)

text: The corpse was to appear to be the victim of an airplane crash, the non-existent Royal Marine Major William Martin, who had letters in a briefcase that hint at a forthcoming Allied invasion of Greece and Sardinia, rather than the obvious target of Sicily.
title: The Man Who Never Was (book)

text: Admiral of the Fleet Sir Arthur John Power (12 April 1889 – 28 January 1960) was a Royal Navy officer.
title: Arthur Power

text: He took part in the First World War as a gunnery officer and saw action in the Dardanelles Campaign.
title: Arthur Power

text: During the inter-war years he commanded the gunnery school at HMS "Excellent" and then the aircraft carrier HMS "Ark Royal" .
title: Arthur Power

text: During the Second World War he played a leading role in the planning for the Allied invasion of Sicily and for the Allied invasion of Italy and then commanded the naval forces for the actual landing of V Corps at Taranto in Italy in September 1943.
title: Arthur Power

text: He went on to be Commander-in-Chief of the East Indies Fleet in the closing stages of the war and conducted naval strikes on the Imperial Japanese Army in Borneo and Malaya.
title: Arthur Power

text: After the War he became Second Sea Lord and Chief of Naval Personnel, Commander-in-Chief, Mediterranean Fleet and then Commander-in-Chief, Portsmouth.
title: Arthur Power

text: HMS "Boreas" was a B-class destroyer built for the Royal Navy around 1930.
title: HMS Boreas (H77)

text: Initially assigned to the Mediterranean Fleet, she was transferred to the Home Fleet in 1936.
title: HMS Boreas (H77)

text: The ship then patrolled Spanish waters enforcing the arms blockade during the first year of the Spanish Civil War of 1936–39.
title: HMS Boreas (H77)

text: She spent most of World War II on convoy escort duties in the English Channel and the North Atlantic, based at Dover, Gibraltar, and Freetown, Sierra Leone.
title: HMS Boreas (H77)

text: "Boreas" also served two brief tours with the Mediterranean Fleet and participated in Operation Husky, the 1943 Allied invasion of Sicily.
title: HMS Boreas (H77)

text: She was loaned to the Royal Hellenic Navy the next year after conversion into an escort destroyer.
title: HMS Boreas (H77)

text: She was renamed "Salamis" and served in the Aegean for the rest of the war.
title: HMS Boreas (H77)

text: "Salamis" became a training ship after the war until she was returned to Britain and scrapped in 1951.
title: HMS Boreas (H77)

text: Operation Mincemeat was a successful British disinformation strategy used during the Second World War.
title: Operation Mincemeat

text: As a deception intended to cover the 1943 Allied invasion of Sicily, two members of British intelligence obtained the body of Glyndwr Michael, a homeless man who died from eating rat poison, dressed him as an officer of the Royal Marines and placed personal items on him identifying him as Captain (Acting Major) William Martin.
title: Operation Mincemeat

text: Correspondence between two British generals which suggested that the Allies planned to invade Greece and Sardinia, with Sicily as merely the target of a feint, was also placed on the body.
title: Operation Mincemeat

text: HMS "Seraph" (pennant number P219) was an S-class submarine of the British Royal Navy.
title: HMS Seraph (P219)

text: She carried out a number of intelligence and special operations activities during World War II, the most famous of which was Operation Mincemeat.
title: HMS Seraph (P219)

text: The 1945 VFL Grand Final was an Australian rules football game contested between the South Melbourne Football Club and Carlton Football Club, held at Princes Park in Melbourne on 29 September 1945.
title: 1945 VFL Grand Final

text: It was the 49th annual Grand Final of the Victorian Football League, staged to determine the premiers for the 1945 VFL season.
title: 1945 VFL Grand Final

text: The match, attended by 62,986 spectators, was won by Carlton by a margin of 28 points, marking that club's seventh premiership victory.
title: 1945 VFL Grand Final

text: The game is well remembered for its extremely rough and violent nature, and has commonly been referred to as The Bloodbath.
title: 1945 VFL Grand Final

text: Gray Rothwell "Mick" Sibun (12 April 1929 – 1 May 2011) was an Australian rules footballer who played for South Melbourne Football Club in the Victorian Football League (VFL) between 1950 and 1956, mainly as a rover and half-forward flanker.
title: Mick Sibun

text: He also played interstate football for Victoria.
title: Mick Sibun

text: Sibun grew up in Albert Park, Victoria, which at the time fell into South Melbourne's recruitment zone.
title: Mick Sibun

text: Along with Bob Giles, Sibun played for South Melbourne Under-19s.
title: Mick Sibun

text: He made his debut for South Melbourne in Round 1 of the 1950 season, kicking two goals on debut in a match the Swans won by 20 points.
title: Mick Sibun

text: Sibun played mainly as a half-forward flanker, kicking 88 goals in his 111-game VFL career, with a best of four goals, which he recorded twice - once in 1953 against Collingwood , and once in 1954, against Carlton After the 1956 season, Sibun left the VFL to become playing-coach at Rupanyup in the Wimmera Football League (WFL).
title: Mick Sibun

text: He captained-coached the club to its first premiership in 1961, and to another in 1963.
title: Mick Sibun

text: In total he played 133 games for Rupanyup.
title: Mick Sibun

text: He is considered by some to be the best footballer to ever play in the WFL.
title: Mick Sibun

text: Jim Cullen (9 June 1878 – 9 May 1954) was a former Australian rules footballer who played with the Essendon Football Club, South Melbourne Football Club and Carlton Football Club in the Victorian Football League (VFL).
title: Jim Cullen

text: He was also listed with the Melbourne Football Club, but never played a game.
title: Jim Cullen

text: The 1909 VFL Grand Final was an Australian rules football game contested between the Carlton Football Club and South Melbourne Football Club, held at the Melbourne Cricket Ground in Melbourne on 2 October 1909.
title: 1909 VFL Grand Final

text: It was the 12th annual Grand Final of the Victorian Football League, staged to determine the premiers for the 1909 VFL season.
title: 1909 VFL Grand Final

text: The match, attended by 37,759 spectators, was won by South Melbourne by two points, marking that club's first premiership victory.
title: 1909 VFL Grand Final

text: Darren Crocker (born 26 March 1967) is a former Australian rules footballer and former player of the North Melbourne Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL).
title: Darren Crocker

text: On 16 June 2009, he was appointed caretaker coach of the North Melbourne Football Club after the resignation of Dean Laidley.
title: Darren Crocker

text: On 17 August 2009 the North Melbourne Football Club appointed Brad Scott as their senior coach, thus Crocker was not retained as North Melbourne coach for the 2010 season.
title: Darren Crocker

text: However, he remained as assistant coach at North Melbourne Football Club.
title: Darren Crocker

text: In 2015, Crocker again served as acting coach when Scott underwent back surgery, and again for one match in 2016 when Scott was ill.
title: Darren Crocker

text: The 1907 VFL Grand Final was an Australian rules football game contested between the Carlton Football Club and South Melbourne Football Club, held at the Melbourne Cricket Ground in Melbourne on 21 September 1907.
title: 1907 VFL Grand Final

text: It was the 10th annual Grand Final of the Victorian Football League, staged to determine the premiers for the 1907 VFL season.
title: 1907 VFL Grand Final

text: The match, attended by 45,477 spectators, was won by reigning premiers Carlton by a margin of 5 points, marking that club's second premiership victory and second in succession.
title: 1907 VFL Grand Final

text: The 2000 AFL Grand Final was an Australian rules football game contested between the Melbourne Football Club and the Essendon Football Club, held at the Melbourne Cricket Ground in Melbourne on 2 September 2000.
title: 2000 AFL Grand Final

text: It was the 104th annual Grand Final of the Australian Football League (formerly the Victorian Football League), staged to determine the premiers for the 2000 AFL season.
title: 2000 AFL Grand Final

text: The match, attended by 96,249 spectators, was won by Essendon by a margin of 60 points, marking that club's 16th premiership victory (following Carlton Football Club who also have 16 premierships).
title: 2000 AFL Grand Final

text: Shane Zantuck (born 20 May 1955) is a former Australian rules footballer who played with Melbourne Football Club, North Melbourne Football Club and the South Melbourne Football Club in the Victorian Football League (VFL).
title: Shane Zantuck

text: William Herbert 'Billy' King (17 August 1920 – 23 August 1990) was an Australian rules footballer who played for South Melbourne in the VFL during the 1940s.
title: Billy King (Australian footballer)

text: King, who started his career at South Melbourne in 1940, was recruited from Ascot Vale.
title: Billy King (Australian footballer)

text: Primarily a wingman, he participated in the famous 1945 'Bloodbath' Grand Final which South Melbourne lost to Carlton.
title: Billy King (Australian footballer)

text: In 1947 he represented Victoria at the Hobart Carnival and was selected in the 'Sporting Life' Team of the Year.
title: Billy King (Australian footballer)

text: The 1914 VFL Grand Final was an Australian rules football game contested between the Carlton Football Club and South Melbourne Football Club, held at the Melbourne Cricket Ground in Melbourne on 26 September 1914.
title: 1914 VFL Grand Final

text: It was the 17th annual Grand Final of the Victorian Football League, staged to determine the premiers for the 1914 VFL season.
title: 1914 VFL Grand Final

text: The match, attended by 30,495 spectators, was won by Carlton by a margin of 6 points, marking that club's fourth premiership victory.
title: 1914 VFL Grand Final

text: Dash Radio is a digital radio broadcasting platform with more than 80 original stations.
title: Dash Radio

text: These stations are curated by DJs, radio personalities, musicians, and music tastemakers.
title: Dash Radio

text: The platform includes partner stations curated by Snoop Dogg, Odd Future, Kylie Jenner, Lil Wayne, Tech N9ne, Borgore, B-Real of Cypress Hill, XXL Magazine, and others.
title: Dash Radio

text: Dash Radio has no subscription fees and is commercial-free.

text: Speed Demos Archive (commonly known as simply SDA) is a website dedicated to video game speedruns. SDA's primary focus is hosting downloadable, high-quality speedrun videos, and currently has runs of over eleven hundred games, with more being added on a regular basis.
title: Speed Demos Archive

text: SDA also hosts two annual speedrunning charity marathons, Awesome Games Done Quick and Summer Games Done Quick.
title: Speed Demos Archive

text: It has so far hosted thirteen marathons, and has raised over $10 million for various charities, with the most successful so far being Awesome Games Done Quick 2017, which raised over $2.2 million for the Prevent Cancer Foundation.
title: Speed Demos Archive

text: Mychal Ramon Jefferson, better known under the screen name Trihex, is an American professional gamer and speedrunner.
title: Trihex

text: Active at the biannual Games Done Quick events, Trihex is best known for his runs of "Jet Set Radio" and "Yoshi's Island".
title: Trihex

text: He is a very popular livestreamer, with over 200,000 followers on Twitch.
title: Trihex

text: He is also known to be the face of the Twitch emote, TriHard.
title: Trihex

text: Twitch is a live streaming video platform owned by Twitch Interactive, a subsidiary of Amazon.com.
title: Twitch.tv

text: Introduced in June 2011 as a spin-off of the general-interest streaming platform, Justin.tv, the site primarily focuses on video game live streaming, including broadcasts of eSports competitions, in addition to creative content, "real life" streams, and more recently, music broadcasts.
title: Twitch.tv

text: Content on the site can either be viewed live or via video on demand.
title: Twitch.tv

text: Quake done Quick is a series of machinima and speedrun movies in which Quake, its mission packs, and a few of its related games, are completed as fast as possible, utilizing any shortcut or trick, such as bunny hopping and rocket jumping (but not cheats) necessary.
title: Quake Done Quick

text: These movies are available in the game engine's native demo format and in rendered multimedia versions such as AVI files.
title: Quake Done Quick

text: Lee Young-ho (born 5 July 1992 이영호) is a South Korean "" and "StarCraft II" player who played Terran for the Korean pro-gaming team KT Rolster under the alias By.FlaSh or simply Flash.
title: Flash (video gamer)

text: He is widely considered the best "StarCraft" player of all time.
title: Flash (video gamer)

text: Lee began playing "StarCraft II" competitively in 2011, until his retirement in December 2015.
title: Flash (video gamer)

text: He subsequently returned to playing "Starcraft: Brood War", and started his personal broadcast in February 2016 on the AfreecaTV personal broadcasting platform.

text: Since returning to "Brood War", Lee has won first place in both Season 2 and Season 3 of the Afreeca Starleague.

text: Games Done Quick is a biannual video game speedrun charity marathon held in the United States, originally organized by the Speed Demos Archive and Speedruns Live communities.
title: Games Done Quick

text: Since 2015, it has been handled by Games Done Quick, LLC.
title: Games Done Quick

text: Held since 2010, the events have raised money for several charities; the most common two being the Prevent Cancer Foundation and Doctors Without Borders.
title: Games Done Quick

text: The events are broadcast live on Twitch.
title: Games Done Quick

text: Viewers are encouraged to donate for incentives during the stream such as naming characters in a run, having the runners attempt more difficult challenges, or winning prizes.
title: Games Done Quick

text: Over $12 million has been raised across seventeen marathons.
title: Games Done Quick

text: Summer Games Done Quick 2016 (sometimes abbreviated as SGDQ 2016) was a speedrun charity marathon hosted by the Speedruns Live community on 3–9 July, 2016.
title: Summer Games Done Quick 2016

text: Held at the Hilton Minneapolis Downtown in Minneapolis, Minnesota, the event consisted of 177 consecutive speedruns, spread over seven days.
title: Summer Games Done Quick 2016

text: Participants played through a large variation of video games, including games in the "Super Mario" and "The Elder Scrolls" series.
title: Summer Games Done Quick 2016

text: The event included multiple races, blindfolded play-throughs, and two "Tetris" competitions.
title: Summer Games Done Quick 2016

text: Summer games Done Quick 2016 raised $1,297,924.44 USD for Doctors Without Borders, a slight improvement over the 2015's Summer marathon.
title: Summer Games Done Quick 2016

text: Noirhouse is an award winning Australian dark comedy indie web series, starring Melanie Irons, Nathan Spencer and Mick Davies.
title: Noirhouse

text: It plays on film-noir archetypes, featuring three main characters - a shady detective, femme fatale and Russian mobster.

text: It premiered in September 2013 with an early screening at the Peacock Threater in Hobart, before beginning broadcast on its own website for a 3 episode first series.
title: Noirhouse

text: It was picked up by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for a six episode second season to be released on its iView broadcasting platform, to begin running in November 2014.
title: Noirhouse

text: It was originally funded by Screen Tasmania and Screen Australia.
title: Noirhouse

text: LIVE365 is an Internet radio broadcasting and listening network where users are able to create their own online radio stations, or choose to listen to thousands of human curated stations created by people from around the globe.
title: Live365

text: LIVE365 is unique in that online radio stations on the LIVE365 network were created and managed by music and talk enthusiasts, including both hobbyists and professional broadcasters.
title: Live365

text: LIVE365 also has many well established AM and FM stations that utilized the LIVE365 broadcasting platform to simulcast their terrestrial radio streams via the Live365 distribution network.
title: Live365

text: The Live365 network also features radio stations from well-known artists such as Johnny Cash, David Byrne, Pat Metheny, Jethro Tull, Frank Zappa, and more.
title: Live365

text: LIVE365 was created in 1999, and remains one of the longest running internet radio websites for listeners and broadcasters.
title: Live365

text: "The Man from Jupiter" is the fourth episode of the third season of the American animated television series "Archer".

text: Meanwhile, a group of Cuban hitmen set out to kill Sterling.

text: "Archer" is an American animated comedy series created by Adam Reed for the FX network.
title: List of Archer episodes

text: Too Scared to Scream (also known as "The Doorman") is a 1985 Independent Film/Thriller/Horror movie.

text: Béatrice Picard, {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} , {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (born July 3, 1929 in Montreal, Quebec) is a Canadian actress.
title: Béatrice Picard

text: She is well known in Quebec for the countless roles she has played on the French Canadian theatre and television scene during an ongoing acting career spanning over six decades.
title: Béatrice Picard

text: She became a household name in Quebec for her acting role as Angelina Desmarais in one of the first French Canadian "télé-roman" series called "Le survenant" in the early days of French-speaking television.

text: She then went on to a prolific career in televised comedies such as "Cré Basil" and "Symphorien".

title: Béatrice Picard

title: Béatrice Picard

text: Partition chromatography theory and practice of was introduced through the work and publications of Archer Martin and Richard Laurence Millington Synge during the 1940s.
title: Partition chromatography

text: The process of separating mixtures of chemical compounds by passing them through a column that contained a solid stationary phase that was eluted with a mobile phase (column chromatography) was well known at that time.
title: Partition chromatography

text: Chromatographic separation was considered to occur by an adsorption process whereby compounds adhered to a solid media and were washed off the column with a solvent, mixture of solvents, or solvent gradient.
title: Partition chromatography

text: In contrast, Martin and Synge developed and described a chromatographic separation process whereby compounds where partitioned between two liquid phases similar to the separatory funnel liquid-liquid separation dynamic.
title: Partition chromatography

text: This was an important departure, both in theory and in practice, from adsorption chromatography.
title: Partition chromatography

text: Krystal Meadows (born 1984) is a Canadian stage and voice actress from Stratford, Ontario, best known for voicing Abby Archer on the animated television series, "Grossology".
title: Krystal Meadows

title: Krystal Meadows

title: Krystal Meadows

title: Krystal Meadows

title: Krystal Meadows

text: Cheryl Tunt is a fictional character from the American television series "Archer".
title: Cheryl Tunt

text: Cheryl, a secretary for Malory Archer, collaborates with seven other field operatives of the International Secret Intelligence Service (ISIS), an illegal intelligence agency headquartered in New York City.

text: Symphony Silicon Valley is the professional symphony orchestra of San Jose and the South Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area.
title: Symphony Silicon Valley

text: Founded in 2002 following the demise of the San Jose Symphony, the orchestra debuted to rave reviews and standing ovations on November 23, 2002 at the San Jose Center for the Performing Arts.
title: Symphony Silicon Valley

text: Started initially by Ballet San Jose as a way to keep their core musicians employed and in town after the closure of the San Jose Symphony, the orchestra was so successful that it was spun off as its own separate nonprofit organization after the first year.
title: Symphony Silicon Valley

text: East Foothills is a census-designated place (CDP) in Santa Clara County, California, United States and a neighborhood of San Jose.
title: East Foothills, California

text: The population was 8,269 at the 2010 census.
title: East Foothills, California

text: The area is more commonly referred to as East San Jose, and is located about 4 miles east of downtown San Jose.
title: East Foothills, California

text: This should not be confused with the former city of East San Jose which was annexed by the city of San Jose in 1911.
title: East Foothills, California

text: There have remained some unincorporated pockets surrounded by incorporated San Jose which are now part of a city/county agreement to annex the remaining pockets.
title: East Foothills, California

text: San Jose Secondary Educational Center, Málaga, Spain, was founded by the Society of Jesus in 1906.
title: San Jose Secondary Educational Center

text: It offers education for infant through baccalaureate and initial professional qualification with various training cycles in both middle and high school.
title: San Jose Secondary Educational Center

text: The San Jose Municipal Stadium, or Muni Stadium in common usage, is the home of the minor league baseball San Jose Giants, the Advanced A league affiliate of the San Francisco Giants located in San Jose, California.
title: San Jose Municipal Stadium

text: The Giants play in the northern division of the California League.
title: San Jose Municipal Stadium

text: The stadium is also home to the San Jose State University Spartans college baseball team for some regular season games (other regular season games are played across Alma Avenue at Blethen Field).
title: San Jose Municipal Stadium

text: The local high school baseball divisions also use Municipal Stadium as their championship field.
title: San Jose Municipal Stadium

text: The stadium also hosts concerts, weddings, dog shows, and many other local events.
title: San Jose Municipal Stadium

text: In the past Muni Stadium has been the home field for the San Jose Owls, San Jose Red Sox, San Jose Pirates, San Jose Missions, the San Jose Bees, and the San Jose Expos.
title: San Jose Municipal Stadium

text: St. Joseph School of San Jose City, N.E., Inc., was founded in 1946.
title: St. Joseph School of San Jose City

text: It was formerly known as St. Joseph School, which was named after the city saint of San Jose City, Nueva Ecija.
title: St. Joseph School of San Jose City

text: This school is a non-profit, private Catholic elementary and secondary school located in the heart of San Jose City, Philippines.
title: St. Joseph School of San Jose City

text: The elementary and secondary school is known as the "Center of Elementary and Secondary Education in San Jose City, Nueva Ecija" because it is located in San Jose City, a city in the central part of the Philippines.
title: St. Joseph School of San Jose City

text: The school's elementary department is situated near the city market, City Hall, along Bonifacio St. while its high school department is situated near Mary Help of Christian Church, hotels and restaurants along Barangay Malasin.
title: St. Joseph School of San Jose City

text: Solar4America Ice at San Jose (formerly the Ice Center of San Jose, Logitech Ice Center, and Sharks Ice at San Jose) is an indoor ice rink in San Jose, California, United States.
title: Solar4America Ice

text: The largest ice rink facility in the Western United States, Solar4America Ice serves as the official training facility for the NHL San Jose Sharks and the home arena for San Jose State University's Spartans hockey team.
title: Solar4America Ice

text: The facility opened in 1994 and was expanded in 2000 and 2005.
title: Solar4America Ice

text: Roofing contractor PetersenDean bought naming rights to the facility in 2016, renaming the facility after its Solar4America solar roofing brand.
title: Solar4America Ice

text: Málaga ( , ] ) is a municipality, capital of the Province of Málaga, in the Autonomous Community of Andalusia, Spain.
title: Málaga

text: With a population of 569,130 in 2015, it is the second-most populous city of Andalusia and the sixth-largest in Spain.

text: The San Jose Center for the Performing Arts is located in downtown San Jose, California.

text: The center's auditorium has 2,677 seats, split into 1,921 orchestra and 756 balcony seats.

text: Live from Daryl's House (simply known as Daryl's House, and often abbreviated as LFDH) is an online series that was first created in fall 2007.
title: Live from Daryl's House

text: The show features singer-songwriter Daryl Hall performing with his band and various guest artists at his home in Millerton, New York.
title: Live from Daryl's House

text: The show provides a performance space that is an alternative to live concerts and studio sessions for popular artists.
title: Live from Daryl's House

text: This allows the artists to "…have fun and [be] creatively spontaneous".
title: Live from Daryl's House

text: The majority of shows include a segment in which Hall and the guest artist prepare food from different cuisines for everyone to eat.
title: Live from Daryl's House

text: The food comes from various local restaurants and the chefs of those establishments walk Hall and guest through the preparation of the food.
title: Live from Daryl's House

text: "Live From Daryl's House" expanded to broadcast TV but remained unchanged.
title: Live from Daryl's House

text: Hall was quoted by Billboard.com as saying "it's an Internet show that is being shown on television, so I'm not adapting the show at all in any way to be a 'TV' show."
title: Live from Daryl's House

text: The show debuted in 95 markets on September 24, 2011, with back-to-back half-hour episodes featuring Train (Episode 33) and Fitz & the Tantrums (Episode 35).
title: Live from Daryl's House

text: Starting with the 66th episode of "Live From Daryl's House", the shows are filmed at Hall's club, Daryl's House, in Pawling, New York.

text: Sudan (수단 ; 水團/水𩜵 ) is a traditional Korean punch made with boiled grain cake balls and honied water.

text: It is usually served during the summer for quenching thirst.

text: Traditionally Sudan was always served during a village rite in 6th month in lunar calendar.

text: Korean farmers prayed for a bountiful harvest and god’s blessing for their life in the future by making food offering including foods and Sudan drink.

text: The Texas Instruments Hex-bus Interface was designed in 1982 and intended for commercial release in late 1983.
title: Hexbus

text: It connected the console to peripherals via a high-speed serial link.
title: Hexbus

text: Though it was prototypical to today's USB (plug and play, hot-swappable, etc.), it was never released, with only a small number of prototypes appearing in collector hands after TI pulled out of the market.
title: Hexbus

text: Several Hex-bus peripherals were planned or produced.
title: Hexbus

text: A WaferTape drive never made it past the prototype stage due to reliability issues with the tapes.
title: Hexbus

text: The 5.25-inch Floppy drive also never made it past the prototype stage, even though it worked.
title: Hexbus

text: Prototype DSDD disk controllers and Video controllers were also made.
title: Hexbus

text: A 4-color Printer-Plotter, a 300-Baud Modem, RS-232 Interface, an 80 column thermal/ink printer, and a 2.8" "Quick Disk" drive were the only peripherals released in quantity, mostly for use with the TI CC-40.
title: Hexbus

text: All Hex-bus peripherals could be used with a TI-99/4A when connected through the Hex-bus Interface, through direct connection to the TI-99/8, or through direct connection to the Texas Instruments Compact Computer 40.
title: Hexbus

text: Punch is a wide assortment of drinks, both non-alcoholic and alcoholic, generally containing fruit or fruit juice.
title: Punch (drink)

text: The drink was introduced from India to the United Kingdom in the early seventeenth century, and from there its use spread to other countries.
title: Punch (drink)

text: Punch is typically served at parties in large, wide bowls, known as "punch bowls".
title: Punch (drink)

text: Ti' Punch (] ; French: "Petit Ponch" ) literally meaning "small punch," is a rum-based mixed drink that is especially popular in Martinique, Guadeloupe, Haiti, French Guiana and other French-speaking Caribbean islands.
title: Ti' Punch

text: It is very similar to the daiquiri, which is usually identified with Cuba.
title: Ti' Punch

text: Bahamas Goombay Punch is a soft drink that is produced in the Bahamas.
title: Goombay Punch

text: It is very sweet and has a high sugar content.
title: Goombay Punch

text: Goombay Punch is widely available throughout the bahamas in 12 fl oz cans as well as 20 fl oz bottles.
title: Goombay Punch

text: 6-packs of the soft drink are also widely available.
title: Goombay Punch

text: The soft drink comes in two varieties, Bahamas Goombay Punch (the stock flavor) and Goombay Fruit Champagne.
title: Goombay Punch

text: The regular flavor is yellow in color (see picture).
title: Goombay Punch
